articles.name: How to use advanced product search
articles.title: How to use advanced product search
articles.body:
How To

How do I use advanced product search?

Follow these steps

Search for products in your GlobalTill database using an advanced selection of filters. Follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > Advanced Search.
  2. Select the drop-down arrow on the product filter bar to expand filter options.
  3. Enter the product attributes you wish to search. Then select Filter to display your results on the screen.

Most of the additional filter options are self-explanatory, but here are a few to note.

Agent Number

This is the liquor agency number from the Alberta Gaming and Liquor Commission (AGLC). It is supported for Alberta Liquor customers only.

No Barcode on File
Select Unknown to show products both with and without barcodes. No shows products without a barcode on file. Yes shows products with one or more barcodes on file.
Product Currently in Stock

Select Unknown to show products both in stock and out of stock. Note: This is based on on-hand inventory (your total number, not the quantity available).

articles.name: How to enable block transactions with insufficient inventory
articles.title: How to enable block transactions with insufficient inventory
articles.body:
How To

How do I prevent checking out a sale at the POS when there's insufficient inventory on-hand to cover all items?

Follow these steps

Block Transactions is a POS setting that prevents a salesperson from completing a sale if there's insufficient inventory to cover all the items in the transaction. Manager accounts and higher will receive a warning message, with the option to override this block and finalize the transaction.

To enable blocking transactions with insufficient inventory, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enable Block Transactions.

articles.name: How to create an inventory count from negatives
articles.title: How to create an inventory count from negatives
articles.body:
How To

How do I create an inventory count of all negative quantities in my store?

Follow these steps

The Create Count from Negatives creates a standard cycle count with all negative items, including inactive products, in your store's Main inventory location and allows you to make corrections before posting the inventory count.

To create an inventory count from negatives, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > Count Inventory.
  2. Select Actions > Create Count from Negatives, then select Submit to confirm you want to create the count.
  3. This creates a cycle count with all the negative items in your store's main inventory location to allow you to count and correct them.

More Information

For more information on inventory counts, see the article What is an inventory count.

articles.name: How to enable web product status
articles.title: How to enable web product status
articles.body:
Heads up

Use Bulk Set Attributes to change the web status on multiple products at once.

How To

How do I make a product available for purchase through eComm and other online purchase channels? 

Follow these steps

The web product flag determines what items pass through the API for all online integrations. If the Web product box isn't checked off in the product attributes, an item won't be available in GT Commerce, Shopify, WooCommerce, or any click & collect integrations.

Once web product status is enabled, the Web Data tab is added to the product details page. This is where you'll manage web specific product attributes.

To enable web product status on a single product, follow these steps:

  1. Select Products > List. Locate the product and open it.
  2. Select Actions > Edit Product.
  3. Check Web product on the Basic Information tab.

To enable web product status in bulk, use Bulk Set Attributes, or use the web_product header on the web data import via Admin Ops. See the article, How to upload or edit web product data using admin ops.

  Heads up

You can use the new product list to verify the web status of multiple products at once.

More Information

For more information about managing web products, see the articles:

  • How to edit web product data
  • How to enable web product status by default
  • What criteria controls product availability in online purchase channels?

articles.name: How to allow price embedded or other specialty barcodes
articles.title: How to allow price embedded or other specialty barcodes
articles.body:
How To

How do I allow price embedded or other or specialty barcodes?

Follow these steps

Stores requiring price embedded barcodes (for example, products whose price changes based on weight) can set up the barcode specifications in GlobalTill through POS settings.  

  1. Select POS Settings > POS.
  2. Look for the Barcode settings
  3. Enter Custom Price Embedded Barcode Format to parse price embedded barcodes by matching the output of scale you are using to generate the barcode.
  4. Turn on Non-Alphanumeric Barcodes to include non-alpha number characters such as dashes.
  5. Turn on Allow Stacked Barcodes if you need to take out the UPC code when it is turned on so you can scan barcodes at the POS as if they were any regular consumer items with a UPC-like barcode. This setting is primarily related to regulated industries such as cannabis using the GS1 Expanded DataBar and Expanded Stacked DataBar symbologies. The Expanded DataBars will contain (in this order): GTIN (AI- 01), Expiry Date (AI- 17) OR 500723 if no expiry date, LOT (AI- 10).

articles.name: What are optional manager-only functionality at the POS
articles.title: What are optional manager-only functionality at the POS
articles.body:
What is…

What are the optional manager only functionality at the POS?

Here is a list of functionality that can be added as manager-only functions through POS Settings.

These are settings that can be found under the Settings > POS.

  • Manager Required: No Sale will make No Sale (opening the till drawer without completing a sale) a manager-only function.
  • Manager Required: Safe Drop to make safe drops a manager-only function.
  • Manager Required: Void Invoice to make voiding an entire invoice a manager-only function.
  • Manager Required: Refunds to make performing a refund (checking out with a negative cash balance on an invoice) a manager-only function.
  • Manager Required: Voiding Individual Lines to make deleting products off an invoice (the individual line) a manager-only function.
  • Manager Required: Open Add Points gives managers the ability to add or remove loyalty points at the POS.

articles.name: How to use a child product
articles.title: How to use a child product
articles.body:
How To

What is a child product and how do I use it?

Follow these steps

A child product is a variation of a product that stems from a parent product. Most often, the variation is in the number of units sold as one unit. The parent product is the original form of the product, and the child product is the subsequent product of the parent product with the variation.

A child product is best explained with a real-life example. Your customer walks into your store looking to purchase a single can of beer. Your singles cooler is stocked, but not with the specific brand the customer is looking for. You break down a 6-pack and sell them a single can, then add the remaining units to your singles cooler.

In GlobalTill, the single can of a beer is the child product and the full 6-pack is the parent product.

When scanned at the POS, products with a child product offer the option of selling the child product instead of the parent product.

To use child products in your store, follow these steps.

Create the child product

Before you can assign a child product to a parent product, you must create a SKU for the child product first. To create the child product, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List, then select Actions > New Product.
  2. In this example, for the Product Code we'll copy the SKU from the parent product and append an "/s" to signify it's a single. You can use whichever naming convention makes sense for your store.
  3. Add a Product Name to distinguish it from the parent, and add a Size, Category, and container Deposit for the child product.
  4. From the Ordering tab, add the Supplier and ensure you check Do not reorder. This is to keep sales activity out of the automated ordering calculations, as this is already captured by the parent product.
  5. From the Pricing tab, add the Unit sell and Unit cost for a single unit, then select Submit.

Attach the child product to the parent product

Now we'll attach the child product to the parent product so when the parent is scanned, the button to update the parent product to the child product is enabled. To attach the child product to the parent product, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Locate the parent product and open it.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Product.
  4. Select the Other tab.

  5. Select the Child product from the drop down list, then select Submit.

The resulting scan at the POS

Now when the parent product is scanned at the POS, the single button appears.

  1. The parent product shows up like it usually does, but with the additional button.
  2. Selecting the Single button updates the parent product to the child product.

More Information

For more information about child products, see the article How to manage child product inventory.

articles.name: How to convert a cycle count to a full count
articles.title: How to convert a cycle count to a full count
articles.body:
Before you start

This guide assumes you have already completed and posted a Cycle Count containing all items in your store. Ensure Count Strict Mode is disabled before conversion.

How To

How do I convert a Cycle Count to a Full Count?

Follow these steps

Full Counts in GlobalTill are not recommended with large product databases (50,000+ products), as they may time out or count sheets may fail to generate.

As a work around, we recommend performing a Cycle Count of all items in your store and then converting it to a Full Count. This allows you to capture all products in your store and zero out the inventory for the remaining uncounted items. This is usually performed in multi-store, franchise locations, where a head office manages a large product database, and the store conducting the count carries only a portion of the products and wishes to zero out inventory for all uncounted items.

To create a Cycle Count to convert to a Full Count, follow these steps.

  1. Locate the posted Cycle Count that contains all items in your store. Select the Arrow to open it.
  2. Select Variance Report.
  3. Verify all items in your store are present and have been counted, then select Show More.
  4. After the page refreshes, select Convert to Full Count. Select Submit.

Frequently asked questions

  1. The Show More button is missing from my variance report screen. What should I do?
    Show More is only available when Count Strict Mode is disabled. Disable Count Strict Mode in Other Settings under Settings > Store Settings > Other Settings.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to create a cycle count.

articles.name: How to manage child product inventory
articles.title: How to manage child product inventory
articles.body:
How To

How do I manage inventory for child products?

Follow these steps

A child product is a variation of a product that stems from a parent product. Most often, the variation is in the number of units sold as one unit. The parent product is the original form of the product, and the child product is the subsequent product of the parent product with the variation.

When managing child product inventory, we recommend the following tips.

Setting a product minimum on the parent product

Consider the number of child products you're selling when setting the minimum desired quantity for the parent product. If you you GlobalTill's automated PO generation, this ensures your ordering enough for both the child and the parent product.

To set a minimum desired quantity on the parent product, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Search for and select the parent product then select Actions > Edit Product.
  3. Select the Ordering tab.
  4. Enter a Minimum desired quantity, then select Submit.

Enable do not reorder on child product

Because the child product is created by you in your store, and not purchased directly from a supplier, we recommend you enable Do Not Reorder on the child product's ordering tab. This is to prevent the modified SKU from being added to auto-generated POs.

To enable do not reorder on the child product, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Search for and select the child product, then select Actions > Edit Product.
  3. Select the Ordering tab.
  4. Check Do not reorder, then select Submit.

Use repackage to balance and eliminate negative quantities on child products

Creating a child product covers the physical sale of product variations, however, we recommend using the Repackage function when working with child products to ensure inventory is tracked accurately.

For example, if you sell six single cans of beer as child products that were originally packaged as a 6-pack, the child product SKU would show an inventory of -6 units.

To account for the -6 units, you could repackage one 6-pack with an output quantity of six single cans.

To adjust the inventory by repackaging, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Search for and select the parent product. 
  3. Select the Inventory tab.
  4. Select Repackage.
  5. Enter the child product as the Destination product.
  6. Enter the number of parent products you are converting into child products as the Quantity converting.
  7. Enter the resulting number of child products created as the Output quantity, then select Submit.

More Information

For more information about child products, see the article How to use a child product.

articles.name: How to enable user login after each transaction
articles.title: How to enable user login after each transaction
articles.body:
How To

How do I force a login after each transaction?

Follow these steps

Login after each transaction is a setting that automatically logs the current user out of the POS after any transaction is complete.

To require users to login at the POS after each transaction, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings.
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enable Login After Each Transaction.

articles.name: How do I resolve the error message: This count is too large to load?
articles.title: How do I resolve the error message: This count is too large to load?
articles.body:
Question

I'm getting the following error message when attempting to perform a full inventory count, "This count is too large to load. To perform a Full Count, create a Cycle Count first and convert it to a Full Count." What should I do?

Answer

This error message is displayed when a count exceeds 50,000 items. Full Counts in GlobalTill are not recommended with large product databases, as they may time out or count sheets may fail to generate.

As a work around, we recommend performing a Cycle Count of all items in your store and then converting it to a Full Count. This will allow you to count all physical products in your store and zero out the remaining inventory for items that are not carried or are no longer in stock.

For a step by step guide on converting a Cycle Count to a Full Count, see the article How to convert a cycle count to a full count.

articles.name: Why is a unit cost unusually high?
articles.title: Why is a unit cost unusually high?
articles.body:
Question

The unit cost of one of my products is unusually high. Is there anything that might be causing this?

Answer

Higher than average unit costs are a common symptom of units per case errors in product data, unit cost equals the case cost divided by the units per case.

If you notice an unusually high unit cost on one of your products, it's likely this product was received on a supplier invoice with the units per case set to 1, and as a result, it's assumed the entire case cost as the unit cost.

To remedy this, see the article How to fix a product that has case price instead of unit price.

Why these errors occur

There's multiple ways the default units per case value can be incorrectly calculating unit cost:

  • Global Till requires the default units per case value to be set when a product is created, if this wasn't filled in correctly it needs to be updated.
  • When a supplier invoice is posted, the default units per case for the product will be updated and saved. Managers should be careful to double check that supplier invoices have the correct units per case before posting them, especially if products have the units per case is set to 1.
  • When products are added to Global Till automatically from an integrated supplier like Connect Logistics or BDL, GlobalTill will attempt to set the units per case for you automatically. This works with some products but not all. (For example, this does not happen with allocated products or many BDL products, that do not have the information publicly available). In this situation, GlobalTill will assume the unit per case is 1.

To help you flag potential problems GlobalTill has a couple of quality of life features. On the cost changes page when performing post & receive invoicing new products are tagged with New, and existing products with large changes in cost are highlighted in red.

If you post a supplier invoice with the incorrect unit per case, cost errors on products will occur such as the example below.

More Information

For more information, see the articles:

  • How to fix a product that has case price instead of unit price
  • What is units per case

articles.name: How to enable price check at the POS
articles.title: How to enable price check at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I display a price check button on the POS screen?

Follow these steps

This setting adds a price check button to the POS that allows salespeople to scan a product to check its price without adding it to the transaction.

To enable a price check button at the POS, follow these steps:

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enable Price Check Button.

More Information

For more information, see the articles How to price check at the POS and How to keep price check enabled until manually deactivated.

articles.name: Why is the web data tab missing from a product?
articles.title: Why is the web data tab missing from a product?
articles.body:
Question

Why is the Web Data tab missing from a product's details page?

Answer

If the Web Data tab is missing from a product's details page, it's likely the product isn't configured as a web product.

Enable web product status by selecting Actions > Edit Product, and checking the Web product box. If your data is controlled in a primary environment, reach out to your organization's data management team to request they enable web product status.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to enable web product status.

articles.name: How to add a name to a transaction with a walk in customer
articles.title: How to add a name to a transaction with a walk in customer
articles.body:
How To

How do I add a name to a transaction if the customer doesn't want to create a profile?

Follow these steps

The Add Name button can be enabled in your POS settings to add a name to a transaction when a Walk In Customer is selected.

To enable the add name button, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enable Add Name Button.

articles.name: How to enable full screen view of parked invoices
articles.title: How to enable full screen view of parked invoices
articles.body:
How To

How do I turn on the full screen view of parked invoices?

Follow these steps

This setting allows parked invoices to be viewed in a full screen view rather than a modal view.

To enable the full screen view of parked invoices, follow these steps.

  1. Access POS Settings. 
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enable Full Screen Parked Invoices to enable the Parked Orders menu option.
  4. Select Parked Orders to see all of the currently parked orders.

articles.name: How do I locate inactive products in my store?
articles.title: How do I locate inactive products in my store?
articles.body:
Question

How can I find inactive products in my store?

Answer

Locate inactive products in your GlobalTill database with the following methods.

Search for them

If you know the SKU, name or supplier of the inactive product, search for it in the GT Backend. 

  1. Enter the SKU, name or supplier in the top search bar. 
  2. If there are inactive products, select Show Non-Active just below the search message.

Filter the New Product List to inactive SKUs

View a list of inactive products in the UI.

  1. Go to Products > New List.
  2. Ensure Hide Non-active is unselected.
  3. Select Column Visibility to add the column Flag: Active.
  4. Select the up and down arrows to sort the list. A checkmark indicates Active, an X indicates inactive.

Generate a report 

Use GT Reporting to generate a per SKU breakdown of inactivate products in your database.

  1. Go to Reporting (Beta) > Report List > Inventory.
  2. Select Inactive Products.
  3. Enter the parameters and select Submit.

articles.name: Can you only add barcodes in the GT Backend?
articles.title: Can you only add barcodes in the GT Backend?
articles.body:
Question

Can you only add barcodes in the admin or GT Backend?

Answer

Yes. You can only add barcodes in the GT Backend at this time. We do plan to add support for adding barcodes via our mobile app in the near future.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to add a barcode.

articles.name: How do I see a list of all items that are pending return?
articles.title: How do I see a list of all items that are pending return?
articles.body:
Question

How do I see a list of all items that are pending return?

Answer

Step 1: View all pending returns.
  1. Go to Products >  New List.
  2. Select Columns and make sure Qty Pending Return is selected.
  3. Sort the column from highest to lowest and if there are any products pending return they will be highlighted.
Step 2: Find the supplier invoice for a pending return?
  1. Select Purchasing > Supplier Invoices.
  2. Expand the search filter.
  3. Under Posted, select No.
  4. Select Submit
  5. Invoices that are unposted with line items in the negative are Pending Return.

articles.name: How to customize quick tender buttons
articles.title: How to customize quick tender buttons
articles.body:
How To

How do I change the amounts on the quick tender buttons at the POS?

Follow these steps

  1. Select POS Settings > Payment.
  2. Under Quick Tender Buttons enter the quick cash amounts POS based on your region’s currency.   



  3. The Exact Cash button can also be turned on or off.

articles.name: How to turn on auto print
articles.title: How to turn on auto print
articles.body:
How To

What is auto print and when should I use it?

Follow these steps

Automatic printing will automatically trigger the receipt to print without user input. When turned off, the user must manually press the print button to print a receipt. However, some types of receipts cannot be suppressed and will automatically print regardless of this setting such as debit terminal merchant copies.

To turn on Auto Print, follow these steps:

  1. Select POS Settings > Printing.
  2. Turn on Auto Print.

articles.name: How to turn on stay on print screen
articles.title: How to turn on stay on print screen
articles.body:
How To

What is stay on print screen and how do I turn it on?

Follow these steps

Stay on Print Screen keeps receipts visible until a Done button is pressed or another product is scanned to start a new transaction.

To turn on Stay on Print Screen, follow these steps.

  1. Select POS Settings > Printing.
  2. Turn on Stay on Print Screen.

articles.name: How to print return info on receipts
articles.title: How to print return info on receipts
articles.body:
How To

How do I print return info on receipts?

Follow these steps

When turned on, the POS will print an additional area on return receipts to capture customer name, phone, and signature, as well as employee name and signature.

To turn on Return Info Collection, follow these steps:

  1. Select POS Settings > Printing.
  2. Enable Print Return Info Collection.

articles.name: How to turn on auto refresh the POS
articles.title: How to turn on auto refresh the POS
articles.body:
How To

What is auto-refresh and how can I enable it at the POS?

Follow these steps

Auto Refresh periodically resets the GlobalTill POS window during periods of inactivity.  When some computer systems continually remain on the GlobalTill POS window, excess memory usage can cause unusual system slowness and errors.  Auto Refresh resets the window and prevents such memory usage from occurring. If you notice a recurring problem with slowness or errors, try enabling Auto Refresh to see if the problem is corrected.

  1. Select POS Settings > Admin.
  2. Turn on Auto Refresh.

articles.name: How to set up a customer display window
articles.title: How to set up a customer display window
articles.body:
How To

How do I set up a customer-facing display screen at my POS station?

Follow these steps

Customer Display is a secondary display window used with a customer-facing monitor. To set up customer display, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings.
  2. Select the Admin tab.
  3. Select Toggle Customer Display to open a customer display window.
  4. Click and drag the window to your customer-facing monitor.
  5. Optional: Customize the display by adding your store logo or rotating through a folder of advertisements.

articles.name: How to add a store logo at the POS
articles.title: How to add a store logo at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I add my store logo at the POS

Follow these steps

  1. Select POS Settings > Admin.
  2. Under Store Logo, upload the store logo.

articles.name: How to enable auto log out
articles.title: How to enable auto log out
articles.body:
How To

How do I turn on auto log out at the POS station?

Follow these steps

When Auto Log Out is turned on, the current POS user will be automatically logged out after 3 minutes of inactivity. To enable Auto Log Out, follow these steps:

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the Admin tab.
  3. Enable Auto Logout.

articles.name: How to enable quick add keep open
articles.title: How to enable quick add keep open
articles.body:
Heads up

This option is available in POS v4 and above.

How to

How can I keep the quick add window (Flip Chart) open at the POS after making a selection?

Follow these steps

Keep Quick Add Open leaves the Quick Add (Flip Chart) window open until the salesperson manually closes it. This setting is often used when cashiers need to add multiple items using the Quick Add button at the POS.

To enable, follow these steps:

  1. Access the POS settings.
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Turn on Quick Add Keep Open.

More Information

For instructions on how to create and add quick add buttons to the POS, see the article How to create quick add buttons.

articles.name: How to adjust the POS screen size
articles.title: How to adjust the POS screen size
articles.body:
Heads up

Access to the POS settings requires an admin level user account.

How To

How do I adjust the POS screen size?

Follow these steps

Due to differences in screen resolutions and operating systems, you may need to increase or decrease the zoom level in the POS settings. We recommend no higher than 1.2 to avoid potential visual distortion. To adjust the zoom level, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the Core tab.
  3. Adjust the Application Zoom Level.

articles.name: How to enable ID check
articles.title: How to enable ID check
articles.body:
How To

How do I enable age verification at the POS?

Follow these steps

Does your store want to encourage your salespeople to check IDs for age-restricted products such as tobacco or alcohol? There are two options to check IDs at the POS.

  • Force ID Check at Checkout - Prompts the cashier to check for ID automatically when they select the Checkout button. ID Skipped or ID Checked must be selected to proceed.

  • Button Check on POS Screen - Displays the ID button on the POS screen with the required date of birth. This method does not force the cashier to request identification, however, when it is clicked it will be marked on the receipt as checked.

You can select either of the Check ID types but not both. Follow these steps.

  1. Access POS Settings.
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enter the age of majority of the province you're operating in the Identification (ID) Check field. Enable either Force ID Check or Button Check on POS.

articles.name: Why can't I see recent changes to my template?
articles.title: Why can't I see recent changes to my template?
articles.body:
Question

I've renamed or made other changes to a template in the visual editor, but the changes aren't showing up. Why?

Answer

Changes to templates refresh periodically. If you've made recent changes to a template that aren't showing up yet, select Actions > Refresh Visual Templates to refresh.

articles.name: How to assign or edit a product's Other (compliance) category
articles.title: How to assign or edit a product's Other (compliance) category
articles.body:
Before you start

Make sure the Other category exists in your GlobalTill database. If it doesn't, create it under Products > Category Manager.

How To

How do I assign or edit a product's Other (compliance) category?

Follow these steps

To assign or edit a product's Other category, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Locate the product and open it.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Product.
  4. Select the Other tab.
  5. Select the Other category from the dropdown list in the Compliance Category field.

More Information

For more information, see the article What is the Other (compliance) category.

articles.name: How to set product minimums
articles.title: How to set product minimums
articles.body:
How To

How do I set product minimums?

Follow these steps

A product minimum represents the minimum desired quantity of a product that you want in your store at all times.

To set the product minimum follow these steps.

  1. Select Product > List.
  2. Open the product by selecting the Box and Arrow icon.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Product.
  4. Select the Ordering tab.
  5. Enter the Minimum Desired Quantity. Select Submit.

articles.name: What information can be shared between stores?
articles.title: What information can be shared between stores?
articles.body:
Question

What information can be shared between stores?

Answer

Typically, GlobalTill multistore locations can only share product and customer data. Other information is usually accessed and input on a store-by-store basis. 

For Enterprise clients, we can sometimes set up a script that will automate other configurations. However, for most multistore clients, we configure stores individually or guide for the store management to perform set up.

articles.name: How are payments received in WooCommerce captured in GlobalTill?
articles.title: How are payments received in WooCommerce captured in GlobalTill?
articles.body:
Question

How are payments received in WooCommerce captured in GlobalTill? 

Answer

When GlobalTill pulls an order from WooCommerce, it matches the WooCommerce payment method on the order against the existing payment methods in your GlobalTill store.

  • If you have a payment method in the GT Backend that is named exactly the same as the payment method in WooCommerce, the payment will be recorded automatically in GlobalTill.
  • If there is no matching payment method, the order will be imported, but the payment will not be recorded in GlobalTill. The order will include a note stating that the payment could not be found.
  • When a payment method cannot be found, record the payment manually by taking a deposit on the customer order in the GT Backend.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to receive a deposit on a customer order.

articles.name: How to merge customer orders
articles.title: How to merge customer orders
articles.body:
Heads up

Orders must have the same customer and status of either "open" or "picked" in order to be merged.

How To

How do I merge customer orders?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Selling > Customer Orders.
  2. Select the orders to be merged. Use the Shift key to select two at a time.  



  3. Once the orders are selected, select Merge Orders.



  4. The orders will be merged into a single customer order.

articles.name: How to export a purchase order
articles.title: How to export a purchase order
articles.body:
How To

How do I export a purchase order?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Purchasing > Purchase Orders.
  2. From the PO list, locate and select the purchase order you want to export.


  3. Select Export PO. You have four different formats to choose from including, Word, PDF, Excel and SKU, Qty Text Format.

  4. For PDF and Word exports, choose the PO template and select Submit.

articles.name: How to complete a card transaction
articles.title: How to complete a card transaction
articles.body:
How To

Follow these steps

  1. Select Checkout after all products have been entered and the customer has been selected.
  2. Select your payment method. If your store uses an integrated debit/credit terminal, you will only see Cash and Card as payment methods.



  3. If you do not use an integrated debit terminal, you will need to select Show More and then choose the correct payment method each time you perform a transaction.
  4. Once you’ve selected your payment method, move to the terminal, and take the card payment. Once the terminal approves the payment, the POS will complete the transaction automatically. For more information see Card Approval and the iCT250.

articles.name: How to enable numeric login at the POS
articles.title: How to enable numeric login at the POS
articles.body:
Heads up

Numeric login requires all users to have unique pins.

How To

How do I enable numeric login at the POS?

Follow these steps

The default login setting at the POS requires both a username and a PIN. Numeric login allows users to login to the POS using a user-defined PIN only, without having to select a user. This allows the usage of PINs as cashier numbers rather than as traditional PINs.

To enable numeric login, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the Core tab.
  3. Enable Numeric Login.

articles.name: How to adjust OS print settings
articles.title: How to adjust OS print settings
articles.body:
How To

What are OS print settings and how are they adjusted?

Follow these steps

Due to differences in printer manufacturers and drivers, you may need to adjust these settings to increase or decrease the size of your receipts. If your receipts are getting cut off by the printer, you can increase the padding value. The cash drawer is controlled through the printer drivers, typically accessible in the printer settings.

  1. Select POS Settings > Printing.
  2. Adjust the OS Print Settings.  From here you can adjust the size (zoom) of the receipt and the padding.  You can also adjust the debit zoom settings.

articles.name: How to pause or delete a retail pricing rule
articles.title: How to pause or delete a retail pricing rule
articles.body:
How To

How do I pause or delete a retail pricing rule?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Products > Pricing > Retail Prices.
  2. To pause a retail price rule, select Pause.
  3. To delete a retail price rule, select Delete.

articles.name: How to edit a brand
articles.title: How to edit a brand
articles.body:
How To

How do I edit or change a brand?

Follow these steps

  1. Go to Products > Product Management > Brand Manager.
  2. Locate the brand you wish to change and double click it.
  3. Change either the Name, Brand Code, or Brand Specialist.  
  4. Select Submit.

articles.name: How to create inventory reason codes
articles.title: How to create inventory reason codes
articles.body:
How To

How do I create inventory reason codes?

Follow these steps

Use the Reason Code Manager to create reasons, such as breakage, for product inventory changes and adjustments. These inventory reason codes can be used when making individual or bulk inventory adjustments and can be tracked and reported in select reporting.

To create an Inventory Reason Code, follow these steps.

  1. Select Store Settings > Advanced > Reason Code Manager.
  2. Select Actions > Add Reason Code.

  3. To create a new inventory reason code, enter the following:
    • Code - Up to 2 character code to describe the inventory change or adjustments
    • Reason - The long-form description of the reason
    • Active - Select active if the inventory reason code is in use and visible

  4. Select Submit.

articles.name: How to purchase from a U.S. supplier
articles.title: How to purchase from a U.S. supplier
articles.body:
How To

How can I balance a supplier invoice from a foreign supplier?

Follow these steps

As of right now, Forex support is not available within the supplier invoicing system.

If you are looking to balance against your supplier invoice, you can enter the US invoice as if it were in Canadian currency. This works well if you do not use GlobalTill pricing rules or automatic pricing.

If you are using pricing rules to auto set the prices, then it's important that you convert the unit costs to CAD before entering costs into the supplier invoice. This way, you mark up the figure that is closest to the landed costs. If duties and customs fees are significant, it's also good to add an extra percentage to these figures based on that.

Your supplier invoice in GlobalTill will not match the physical invoice, but your profit numbers and prices (if auto-generated) will be more representative of what's actually going on.

articles.name: How to know if a card payment was processed manually or through the payment terminal
articles.title: How to know if a card payment was processed manually or through the payment terminal
articles.body:
How To

How do I tell whether a credit or debit card was processed manually at the POS or through the payment terminal in the GT Backend?

Follow these steps

Locate the invoice in the GT Backend and see whether there is an authorization code next to the payment.

  1. Select Selling > Invoices.
  2. Use Search to locate the invoice.
  3. Select View.
  4. Locate the payment on the invoice.

  • If the card payment was completed through the payment terminal, the GT Backend will record an authorization code next to the payment on the invoice.
  • If the payment was recorded manually through the POS, (usually by selecting Show More and then offline payment button) there will not be a code.

Below, you can see an invoice paid with two different payment methods— a debit card and a Visa card. The payment terminal authorized the debit card. You can tell because the authorization code appears. However, the Visa was recorded manually at the POS because no authorization code exists.

articles.name: What does pending return to vendor mean?
articles.title: What does pending return to vendor mean?
articles.body:
Question

What does the product status Pending Return to Vendor mean?

Answer

Pending Return to Vendor means that you have an open (unposted) supplier invoice with a negative quantity of the product. This negative quantity is flagged as Pending Return to Vendor until the invoice is posted.

Often a store will create a supplier invoice with a negative product quantity when a product is being returned to the supplier. However, the store will not post the invoice until the credit actually appears on a subsequent supplier invoice.

Use the Supplier Invoice Filter to locate the supplier invoice in question. You can look through unposted invoices only by selecting NO under the Posted option.

articles.name: How to create discount reason codes
articles.title: How to create discount reason codes
articles.body:
Heads up

Force assign discount code must be enabled in the POS settings to apply discount codes at the POS. To enable, access the POS Settings > POS Tab > Force assign discount code.

How To

How do I create discount codes?

Follow these steps

Use the Discount Code Manager to create reasons for why a product was sold at a discount. These discounts codes are entered when a product is discounted using an open percent or dollar discount at the POS.

To create a Discount Code, follow these steps.

  1. Select Store Settings > Advanced > Discount Code Manager.
  2. Select Actions > Add Discount Code.
  3. To create a new discount code, enter the following:
    • Code - Up to 2 character code to describe the type of discount being applied
    • Reason - The long-form description of the reason
    • Active - Select active if the inventory reason code is in use and visible
  4. Select Submit to create the discount code. Remember to refresh your POS data and ensure Force assign discount code is enabled in the POS settings before using new discount codes. 

Frequently asked questions

  1. Why isn't a discount code appearing at the POS?
    If a discount code isn't appearing at the POS, consider the following.
    • The prompt for the discount code only applies when using an open percent or dollar discount at the POS.
    • Force assign discount code must be enabled in the POS settings. Access the POS Settings > POS Tab > Force assign discount code.
    • Refresh the POS data to sync the discount codes from the GT Backend to the POS.

articles.name: Where do I find a list of products that a customer has purchased for a specific date range?
articles.title: Where do I find a list of products that a customer has purchased for a specific date range?
articles.body:
Question

Is there a way to review a customer's purchase history, or pull a report to see how much of a certain product a specific customer has purchased in a set time frame?

Answer

Use the Customer Spend Product Detail report located under Reporting (Beta) > Report List > Customer and Loyalty to generate a detailed list of products that a customer has purchased for a specific date range including SKU, category and profit.

Filter the report to see how much of a specific product was purchased in that time.

articles.name: How do I review inventory across multiple stores?
articles.title: How do I review inventory across multiple stores?
articles.body:
Heads up

These methods are for multi-store setups.

Question

How do I review product inventory levels across different locations?

Answer

There are multiple ways to view product inventory levels across multiple stores, below are two common methods.

Individual product inventory across multiple stores

If you're looking to check the inventory status of a single product across all of your stores, follow these steps.

  1. From the main environment, select Products > List.
  2. Locate the product with inventory you'd like to review, and open it.
  3. Select the Inventory tab to see a list of all the locations where the product is being sold, the quantity on hand in each location, and cost and retail price.

Entire product inventory across multiple stores

If you're looking to review inventory levels for all of your products across all of your stores, we recommend generating the Q90 Sales Inventory Multi-store report. The Q90 is a combined inventory and sales report that shows the last 12 weeks of sales and the current inventory on hand for each location.

To generate the Q90, follow these steps.

  1. From the main environment, select Reporting > Report List > Multi-Store Ordering > Q90 Sales Inventory Multistore.
  2. Use the Report Info, Email and Optional tabs to populate your report parameters. Then select Submit to generate the report.

articles.name: If I price based on last ordered cost, will I be notified of supplier cost changes?
articles.title: If I price based on last ordered cost, will I be notified of supplier cost changes?
articles.body:
Question

If I set a Retail Pricing Rule up to price based on the last ordered cost, will I still get a prompt somewhere that the AGLC or BC LDB cost has increased or decreased?

Answer

You can find this information under Reporting > Archived Reports > Price Changes. Any products on file with the AGLC or BCLDB (and their upcoming price changes) will be on this report. The caveat is that the price change wouldn't trigger a suggested retail price change, and would require manual audit of the list.

articles.name: Why is the barcode on my template corrupted?
articles.title: Why is the barcode on my template corrupted?
articles.body:
Question

Why is the barcode field on my template generating a corrupted barcode for certain products? 

Answer

Corrupted barcodes on a template are usually the result of incorrect sizing or image overlap.

Go to the template in question and select the barcode field to resize or move it, if necessary. Or simply Right click on the barcode field, and select Bring to Front.

articles.name: How to enter or edit THC and CBD content
articles.title: How to enter or edit THC and CBD content
articles.body:
How To

How do I enter or update a product's THC or CBD % content?

Follow these steps

To add or update THC or CBD content, follow these steps:

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Locate the product and open it.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Product THC/CBD.
  4. Enter THC and CBD content as absolute values. For example, 29% THC would be entered as 29.

articles.name: Do I set up WooCommerce before or after I begin using GlobalTill?
articles.title: Do I set up WooCommerce before or after I begin using GlobalTill?
articles.body:
Question

I'm new to both GlobalTill and WooCommerce. Which platform should I set up first?

Answer

We recommend setting up GlobalTill first, then configuring WooCommerce to pull the product data from the GT Backend.

Depending on your operations, this timing isn't always possible. Retailers can set up WooCommerce either before or after they begin using GlobalTill, although the timing will impact how you set up the GlobalTill integration. More info can be found in our WooCommerce documentation.

articles.name: What is an inventory count
articles.title: What is an inventory count
articles.body:
What is…

What is an inventory Count? What Types of Inventory Counts are Supported in GlobalTill?
Why Inventory Counts?

In Canada, retail stores have a legal requirement to do an inventory count of all products once every year. However, in practice, stores often perform inventory counts more frequently either by taking an inventory of all products in their store or by counting small subsets of products or sections of a store to maintain the accuracy of inventory records.

We recommend a complete inventory count each month to ensure accuracy. If your store does not have the resources to perform an entire count at once, you can use GlobalTill to do partial counts by category, brand, sub-vendor, or shelf location allowing you to break up your counts over days and weeks.

By performing inventory counts more frequently, managers have more control of the accuracy of their numbers and can more easily piece together the exact reasons why an inventory discrepancy occurred.

Other Benefits include:

  • Accurate quantities at your POS stations to advise customers (resulting in higher customer satisfaction)
  • Ability to use GlobalTill's automated replenishment features
  • Inventory valuation accuracy

Because stores often operate most days a year, closing stores to perform an inventory count is often impractical and costly. This creates additional challenges because inventory counts are often performed while a store is doing business and thus against an inventory that is constantly changing. If you must perform a count when a store is open, count the smallest section of inventory practical and ensure that it is posted immediately to avoid creating discrepancies during the counting process.

Why Might Inventory Discrepancies Occur?

Common purchasing and receiving errors including:

Supplier Invoices
If supplier invoices are not entered correctly, the inventory and cost information flowing into GlobalTill will be incorrect.
SKU Changes
Suppliers often change SKU codes on the same product, re-use UPC codes, and perform other non-standard operations with their product catalog. Occasionally suppliers will inform stores, however, many times they do not. These changes are some of the hardest to notice but easily create discrepancies.
Seasonal Items
Some suppliers use seasonal or special packaging from time to time and these products may be coded incorrectly.
Point-of-Sale
Clerical errors at the point of sale occur to sales clerks adding the wrong product to the invoice at checkout.
Theft
Both external and employee theft is an unfortunate reality for retail businesses.

Frequent counts may give you the information you need to combat this by isolating the section of your store or time that this most often occurs.

What types of counts are supported in GlobalTill?

Full Count
Is a complete inventory count of all your store's products. Any products not counted will be set to 0. This type of count is best performed when the store is closed.
Cycle Count
A cycle count is a count where you count a selection of products or a small section of a store that is not an entire category, subcategories, or area. This is an isolated, individual count that will not affect any other products that are not counted (meaning if you do not count a given product, the inventory for that product will remain the same).
Partial Count
A partial count is a count where you count a specific section of your store. Everything in that section that is not counted will be set to 0 when you post the count because GlobalTill assumes there is none of that product in the store if you did not count it. This type of count is useful because it can tell you about items that you've missed - if you select a category BEER and forget to count Budweiser, GlobalTill will alert you to that before you post your count. If you do not want to unexpectedly set the quantity for zero for your products, you should use a cycle count instead.

GlobalTill supports creating a section of products based on:

  • Category
  • Sub Category
  • Sub Sub Category
  • Shelf Location
  • Brand
  • Supplier
  • Sub Vendor

Frequently asked questions

  1. Where are Inventory Counts Performed in GlobalTIll?
    Select Products > Count Inventory.
  2. Can my store stay open while I count?
    While ideally your store should be closed while performing a count, we realize that this isn't practical for most stores. You can stay open while you count. However, GlobalTill expects the counts to be accurate as of the exact moment you press "Post Inventory Count."
  3. What does this mean "while you are counting?"
    Consider the following examples:
    • Imagine you count 10 (ten) Budweiser 24 Pack Cans and enter the count into GlobalTill. Then, you sell 1 before the count is posted. To have an accurate count, you must adjust Budweiser 24 Pack Cans down to 9 (either by changing the count to 9 or adding a count of -1).
    • If you sell a Bud Light 12 pack but haven't yet gotten around to counting that product, there is no need to adjust the count before you post it.

More Information

For more information, see the articles:

  • How to perform a full count
  • How to perform a partial count
  • How to perform a cycle count

articles.name: How to apply a price book to a customer profile by category
articles.title: How to apply a price book to a customer profile by category
articles.body:
Before you start

Make sure the price book is created first. For more information, see the article How to create a price book.

How To

How do I give a customer special pricing on a specific category of products only?

Follow these steps

Special pricing is used to give a customer a pricing exception on a category of products. The special price will override any other price book or retail pricing.

  1. Select Customers > List.
  2. Locate the customer you want to apply the price book to and select View Customer.
  3. From the Special Pricing tab, select Add Special Price.
  4. Select the Price Book and the Category you want to apply from their respective drop-downs. Select Submit.

More Information

For information on assigning a price book price to all purchases made under a customer account, see the article How to apply a price book to a customer profile.

articles.name: How to delete a customer order
articles.title: How to delete a customer order
articles.body:
How To

How do I delete a customer order?

Follow these steps

If you want to delete a customer order, follow these steps.

  1. Select Selling > Customer Orders.
  2. Select the Blue Arrow next to the customer order you wish to delete.
  3. Select Actions > Delete Entire Order. Select Submit.

articles.name: How to copy a purchase order
articles.title: How to copy a purchase order
articles.body:
How To

How do I copy a purchase order?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Purchase > Purchase Orders.
  2. Locate the purchase order and select it.
  3. Select Actions > Copy PO.
  4. You copied PO will appear in the Purchase Order List.

articles.name: What is the difference between quick post and post & receive
articles.title: What is the difference between quick post and post & receive
articles.body:
What is…

What is the difference between choosing Quick Post and Post & Receive?

Both Quick Post and Post & Receive save and record the supplier invoice, products, and associated costs. The main difference between the two options is Post & Receive offers you the chance to review the invoice one more time before posting.

Post & Receive will flag any products missing barcodes, any new products (which often need extra review because costs or units per case may be incorrect), as well as potential errors in costs when a change in price is too high or too low.

You will also have access to a Receiving Report, which can be printed or exported to Excel to send to an accounting department to match up against what was paid.

Either method will lead to a page asking for additional confirmation before posting the invoice.

articles.name: How to split payments at the POS
articles.title: How to split payments at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I pay for a transaction with more than one card, or with a card and cash at the POS?

Follow these steps

To split the amount due between multiple tenders, follow these steps.

  1. From the checkout screen select Tender Card Amount.

  2. Enter the amount to charge to the first card. Select Enter.

  3. This will populate the amount under Paying Amount. Select the payment method and process as usual for this amount. When you move to your payment terminal you will note that the amount due is only the partial amount, not the full amount.
  4. Once the card has processed, return to your POS to complete your transaction by either repeating the process with a second card or selecting Cash.

articles.name: How to display a support phone number at the POS
articles.title: How to display a support phone number at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I display a support phone number at the POS?

Follow these steps

Enter a support phone number in your POS settings to display it as a badge on the main POS screen.

To display a support phone number at the POS, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings.
  2. Select the Core tab.
  3. Enter a Support Phone Number, if the field is left blank no badge is shown.

articles.name: How to delete a brand
articles.title: How to delete a brand
articles.body:
How To

How do I delete a brand?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Products > Product Manager > Brand Manager. This gives you a list of all the brands you have created in the GT Backend.
  2. To delete a single brand, select the minus (-) next to that brand. Confirm you want to delete the brand. This operation cannot be undone.

articles.name: What is the do not reorder indicator
articles.title: What is the do not reorder indicator
articles.body:
What is

What is the do not reorder indicator?

Do Not Reorder is a flag that prevents a product from being added to automatically generated purchase orders. Do Not Reorder is often used when you want to sell a product in your store that you do not wish to include in automated ordering. Products with Do Not Reorder enabled can still be added to POs manually, provided they are active.

Enable Do Not Reorder in the product settings on the Ordering tab.

A yellow flag next to the supplier on the product details page means Do Not Reorder is enabled.

articles.name: What is the difference between the Weekly Sales Ordering and the Q90 reports?
articles.title: What is the difference between the Weekly Sales Ordering and the Q90 reports?
articles.body:
What is…

What is the difference between the Weekly Sales Ordering Report and Q90 Sales Inventory Report? Which one should I use?

The Weekly Sales Ordering Report and the Q90 Sales Inventory Report both summarize the last 12 weeks of sales with current inventory on hand and detailed product information.

Both reports are used to:

  • Reference recent sales by week and current inventory levels to reorder faster
  • Get a snapshot of your sales and inventory along with key product attributes

What is the difference between the Weekly Sales Ordering Report and Q90 Sales Inventory Report?

The reports differ in the date segmentation. 

  • The Q90 Sales Inventory Report uses fixed calendar weeks 
  • The Weekly Sales Ordering Report uses weeks based on 7-day periods going backwards from today's date

The date segmentation in the Q90 Sales Inventory Repot is centered around the desire to map sales to a retail calendar. A retail calendar is used by some larger retailers to normalize the regular calendar to keep the same number of weekends in every month. Weekends play a big role in sales, using a retail calendar can make the retail budgeting process easier and the sales reporting comparable.

Some organizations don't have the need to use specific calendar weeks for ordering purposes. They are more concerned with total sales, broken week by week, and aren't forecasting or reporting in terms of the definition of a week.

Which report should I use?

It comes down to personal preference. If you prefer date segmentation based around a retail calendar, we recommend using the Q90. If you're more concerned with total sales, broken week by week, we recommend the Weekly Sales Ordering Report.

Ultimately, inventory levels usually have a sufficient buffer to the point where a calendar week vs. seven day rolling week won't materially affect what your store orders.

We've created the following table to help you decide what report is right for you.

Q90 Sales Inventory Report Weekly Sales Ordering Report
Has more periods (12 vs. 6) Has fewer periods (6 vs. 12)
Has the concept of Week 0, which is the current week Has no concept of Week 0, the report will always reflect yesterday and the prior 7 days (inclusive) as Week 1
Shows sales up to the minute Shows sales up to yesterday. Sales actively happening on the current day are not represented in the report.

More Information

For detailed information about each report, check out the Learn More link under each report in the GT Backend. See the article Reporting specifications and guidance.

articles.name: Why should I price based on highest of?
articles.title: Why should I price based on highest of?
articles.body:
Question

Aside from ensuring the highest cost is used for calculating retail prices, is there another reason to use the Highest of the Last Ordered Cost, Cost Average and AGLC/BC LDB Cost?

Answer

Typically there's a bit of variance in these costs, usually related to purchasing on LTO. Choosing the highest allows for pricing to the highest retail price within your purchasing cost range.

The biggest piece with selecting the "Highest of" is to avoid pricing against an LTO cost, though this will depend on your pricing strategy. Some clients prefer to pass these discounts on automatically, where some prefer to purchase with the discount, hold, and set up a specific sale manually to pass on the savings. Some choose not to pass the LTO on at all.

Another honourable mention for using the highest of the three is catching errors. In theory, you could have an incorrect Last Ordered Cost (perhaps a typo on the last receive) and GT wouldn’t necessarily catch it as a typo, but errors are more pronounced when you're using multiple data points.

articles.name: Are the the packaged date and expiry fields on cannabis products saved in GlobalTill?
articles.title: Are the the packaged date and expiry fields on cannabis products saved in GlobalTill?
articles.body:
Question

Are the packaged date and expiry fields on cannabis products captured in GlobalTill?

Answer

When a stacked barcode is scanned in Frontline at the time a product is received, GlobalTill automatically pulls in the date and batch/lot numbers for cannabis products.

articles.name: How to enable web product status by default
articles.title: How to enable web product status by default
articles.body:
Heads up

Default web product status doesn't apply to products that are automatically created, or created in bulk using Load Utilities or Admin Operations. If you import a supplier invoice where GT auto-creates new products, web status must be enabled manually. Update web status from a product's details page or with Bulk Set Attributes.

How To

How do I change the default setting so that all new products in my store are created with web status enabled? 

Follow these steps

To enable default web status on new products, follow these steps.

  1. Select Settings > Store Settings.
  2. Select the Other Settings in the top right-hand corner.
  3. Scroll to the bottom of the screen and check the box beside Default web product.

      Heads up

    Default web product enables web status on all newly created products. Existing products must be updated manually.

More Information

For more information, see the articles:

  • How to enable web product status
  • How to upload or edit web product data using admin ops
  • What criteria controls product availability in online purchase channels?

articles.name: What does each customer order status mean?
articles.title: What does each customer order status mean?
articles.body:
Heads up

If you're a developer with one of our integration partners looking for technical details on order status, see Models > Structures or Models > Enumerations in our API Docs.

Question

What does each customer order status mean and how does the status relate to the available inventory?

Answer

Statuses are assigned to customer orders to indicate where each order is currently sitting in the fulfillment cycle. Each customer order status, the recommended use case, and the impact of the status on the product inventory for items on an order is explained below.

Quote
Represents a quote for a potential customer order. Does not reduce units in status Available for Sale.
Received (New)
The order has been received but not yet acted upon. Inventory on customer orders with this status is removed from Available for Sale and marked as Dedicated to Customers.
On hold
The order has been reviewed and has been placed on hold. Inventory on customer orders with this status is removed from Available for Sale and marked as Dedicated to Customers.
Open (Ready to Pick)
The order has been reviewed and is ready for processing. Inventory on customer orders with this status is removed from Available for Sale and marked as Dedicated to Customers.
Customer Pickup
The order is ready for the customer to pick up, but has not yet been paid or invoiced. Inventory on customer orders with this status is removed from Available for Sale and marked as Dedicated to Customers.
Picked
The order has been picked. Inventory on customer orders with this status is removed from Available for Sale and marked as Dedicated to Customers.
Partially Picked
The order has been partially picked but is not yet ready to be converted to an invoice. Inventory on customer orders with this status is removed from Available for Sale and marked as Dedicated to Customers.
Invoiced
The customer order has been converted to an invoice and is considered finalized. If the invoice is posted, inventory is removed from Dedicated to Customers and deducted from your location's inventory. 
Merged
The order was merged with another order. The new order takes precedence. Orders that have been merged into a new order are left for tracking purposes only. Inventory is tracked on the new merged order and takes on the status Dedicated to Customers.
Cancelled
The order was cancelled. Inventory on customer orders with this status is removed from Dedicated to Customers and re-assigned Available for Sale.

The customer order status directly impacts the inventory status of all products on a customer order. For a breakdown of inventory statuses, see the article What is inventory status.

More Information

For more information, see the article What does the highlighted colour of a customer order represent?

articles.name: Should I create products in WooCommerce or in the GT Backend?
articles.title: Should I create products in WooCommerce or in the GT Backend?
articles.body:
Question

Should I create products in WooCommerce or in the GT Backend?

Answer

Products can be created in either GlobalTill or WooCommerce. This is the retailer’s preference depending on the store’s setup and operations. Some stores choose to create products in the GT Backend and pull that data over to their WooCommerce installation. Others create the products in WooCommerce and pull inventory numbers only from the GT Backend.

articles.name: What are current cost fields
articles.title: What are current cost fields
articles.body:
What is…

What are the Current (Price Book) Cost and Current (Retail) Cost fields? What are they used for?

The values entered in the current cost fields are used as a reference point to override the product's actual cost when calculating price books or retail pricing rules. When used, GlobalTill ignores all other cost values and only references the values entered here.

What are the current cost fields?

  • Current (Price Book) Cost is an optional artificial cost used in Price Book calculations.
  • Current (Retail) Cost is an optional artificial cost used in Retail Pricing Rule calculations.

What are the current cost fields used for?

Current cost fields are typically used when the cost paid for a product differs from the value of the product. They allow you to manipulate the cost that GlobalTill references in the automated features without changing the actual cost value, thus maintaining data accuracy for the purposes of audit, industry regulation, and financial reporting. Here are a few examples of when you might want to use the current cost fields.

  • Example A. Suppose you buy a product from your supplier on sale, for $6.00, but it usually costs $6.50. You don’t want to factor the discount into your price book pricing. By entering $6.50 into the product's Current (Price Book) Cost field, you can manipulate the calculation for the price book price of that product without modifying the actual cost data in GlobalTill.
  • Example B. You want to align the retail pricing rule prices of several products with slightly different costs. By entering the same value in the each product's Current (Retail) Cost field, the retail pricing rule will calculate the retail price against this artificial cost and generate the same price for each of the products.
  • Example C. The automated pricing for a product seems off and you want to reset the calculation.

More Information

For more information, see the articles:

  • How to use current cost fields to reset automated prices
  • What is a price book
  • What is a retail pricing rule

articles.name: How to perform a full inventory count
articles.title: How to perform a full inventory count
articles.body:
Heads up

You must count all products in your store in a full count otherwise they will be set to quantity a of 0 when you post your count. Review uncounted products by clicking on Not Counted in the top right hand corner, or on the bottom half of the variance report screen before posting.

How To

How do I perform a full inventory count?

Follow these steps

A full inventory count is a count of every product in your store. A full count requires you to count all of your inventory at once—anything you don't count is set to zero, if not already at zero.

Setting up a full inventory count and counting products

To setup and start a full inventory count, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > Count Inventory, then select New Count.
  2. Give your count a Name.
  3. Choose Type - Full Count.
  4. Select the inventory Location then select Submit.
  5. Record the quantities of each product you count using Quick Add Product if you're not using a scanner, or Rapid Count if you are using a scanner.
    • To use Quick Add Product, start by typing either the product name or SKU in the Product field to search for the product, then enter its Quantity. Once the product and quantity are correct, select Add.
    • To use a scanner with Rapid Count, select Actions > Rapid Count and follow the prompts. See the article How to use rapid count.
  6. Optional: To find a product that you've already counted, use the Go to an Existing Count > Go To Product field to search for it and select Go.

Once you're done counting the next step is to look at the variance report.

Handling variances

Variances occur when the number of units you've counted differ from the number of units on hand in the GT Backend. Some stores require you to add a reason for each discrepancy before posting.

To view a count's variance report, follow these steps.

  1. From an un-posted count, select Variance Report.
  2. The variance report shows you the quantity counted during the count, the current inventory as it is recorded in the GlobalTill Backend, and the difference between the two.

If you've miscounted and you need to correct your count, follow these steps.

  1. From the variance report, select Go Back.
  2. Select the Pencil icon of the product you want to correct.
  3. Edit the Product, the Quantity Counted, and select Submit.

If the count is correct, there is a variance, and your store requires reason codes, follow these steps.

  1. From the variance report select the icon under the Modify column for the product with the variance.
  2. Select a Reason for the variance, enter any Notes to explain the situation, and then select Submit.

Once all variances are corrected or accounted for, or if your store doesn't require reason codes, you can post the count.

Posting an inventory count

To post a full inventory count, follow these steps.

  1. From an un-posted full inventory count's variance report select Post Inventory Counts. You'll be asked to confirm before any changes happen. Remember, all products under the not counted list are automatically set to zero once posted.
  2. Once a count is posted, the Inventory Tab of a products detail page is updated. Adjustments from a posted Inventory count are marked as Count.

Frequently asked questions

  1. Can I perform a count while my store is open?
    It depends. Inventory is adjusted when your count is posted. This means if you begin a count during business hours and process sales before the count is posted, the starting number of units you're counting against may no longer be accurate at the time you post the count.
    For example, you have ten units of Widget K on hand when you begin your count. If you count ten units, but sell one unit before posting the count, your inventory will be adjusted to ten units when posting the count. This offsets the sale transaction and overstates the actual on hand inventory by one unit.
    If you choose to perform a count during business hours, keep track of each item sold and adjust the number of units after you post your count.

articles.name: How to display the date and time at the POS
articles.title: How to display the date and time at the POS

How do I display the date and time at the POS?

articles.name: How to delete unused brands
articles.title: How to delete unused brands

These instructions explain how to delete all unused brands, for instructions on how to delete a single brand, see this support article.

How do I delete unused brands?

Follow these steps
