articles.name: How to enable a maximum salesperson discount
articles.title: How to enable a maximum salesperson discount
articles.body:
Heads up

Max Salesperson Discount is also the threshold for Price Match and Manufacturer Coupons if these settings are also activated.

How To

How do I set up a maximum salesperson discount?

Follow these steps

If you want salespeople to be able to discount up to a certain percentage and/or dollar amount off of a specific product at the POS, you need to have Maximum Salesperson Discount enabled in the POS Settings. 

To enable the maximum salesperson dollar and/or maximum salesperson percentage discounts, follow these steps:

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enter the Maximum Sales Person Discount for the dollar and/or percentage value you do not want to exceed.

More Information

For more information, see the following articles:

  • How to discount a line item
  • How to enable price matching
  • How to enable manufacturers coupons at the POS

articles.name: How to turn on print receipts on void
articles.title: How to turn on print receipts on void
articles.body:
How To

What is print receipts on void and when should I use it?

Follow these steps

When Print Receipts on Void is turned on, the POS will print a receipt copy whenever the user voids a transaction at the POS. The receipt will show the message "SALE VOIDED - DO NOT PAY."

Follow these steps:

  1. Select POS Settings > Printing.
  2. Enable Print Receipt on Void.

articles.name: Why is there a variance between the POS end of shift summary and the daily sales reports?
articles.title: Why is there a variance between the POS end of shift summary and the daily sales reports?
articles.body:
Question

Why is there a difference in sales figures between the End of Shift Summary printed out at the POS and certain daily sales reports?

Answer

The End of Shift Summary only captures transactions processed through the POS station.

If you operate a POS station, and process transactions through the GT Backend, it's normal to see a variance between the End of Shift Summary and the daily sales reports because the transactions processed through the GT Backend aren't included in the End of Shift Summary.

To review transactions processed through the GT Backend, follow these steps.

  1. Select Selling > Invoices.
  2. Invoices without a System number indicated the sale was processed in the GT Backend.

articles.name: How to review product inventory level at the POS
articles.title: How to review product inventory level at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I review a product's inventory levels at the POS?

Follow these steps

To review a product's inventory information at the POS, follow these steps.

  1. Scan in the product that you want to check the inventory for.
  2. Select the Window icon to the left of the product.
  3. From the pop-up window, you can see information on product quantity Available, Dedicated to Customers, Coming for Stock, and Pending Return.

      Heads up

    Multi-store environments will also include inventory levels at linked locations.

articles.name: Why aren't the number of transactions always equal to sales plus returns in GT Reporting?
articles.title: Why aren't the number of transactions always equal to sales plus returns in GT Reporting?
articles.body:
Heads up

This article applies to reports in the GT Reporting (Beta) module.

 

Question

Why aren't the Number of Transactions always equal to the Number of Sales plus the Number of Returns in GT Reporting?


In this example, Kelsey R has 10 transactions, but only 8 sales and 1 return.

Answer

Invoices where the total is $0.00 count as a transaction, but not as a sale or a return. Examples are voids and product exchanges of equal value.

Value definitions (find this on the Learn More tab of most Beta reports)

# Transactions
The number of transactions, which includes both sales, returns and exchanges.
# Sales
The number of sales, which includes invoices where the total is greater than 0.
# Returns
The number of returns, which includes invoices where the total is less than 0.

In this example, Kelsey R processed 10 transactions total, but one transaction didn't count as a sale or a return.

# Transactions
10 total transactions, which includes both sales, returns and exchanges.
# Sales
8 sales invoices, where the invoice total is greater than 0.
# Returns
1 return invoice, where the invoice total is less than 0.
Non-sale and Non-return
1 invoice where the total is equal to 0, which could be either a void or a product exchange of equal value.

articles.name: How to apply a new tax profile to an invoice
articles.title: How to apply a new tax profile to an invoice
articles.body:
Heads up

Invoices must be in open status (unposted) to be modified.

How To

How do I apply a new tax profile to an invoice?

Follow these steps

Many e-commerce retailers sell across multiple jurisdictions and require additional tax profiles. To update the taxes on an invoice, follow these steps.

  1. Open the invoice requiring a tax profile update (before posting).
  2. Select Actions > Edit.
  3. Select the wrench icon in the top right corner.
  4. Select Apply Tax Profile.
  5. Select the Tax Profile to apply to the invoice and then select Submit.

  Heads up

To exclude a product from the tax profile update, remove it from the invoice and re-add it after the tax profile has been applied. The product will be added back with the store level assigned tax rate.

articles.name: Why is my liquor order import failing?
articles.title: Why is my liquor order import failing?
articles.body:
Question

I'm getting a 500 error when trying to import my Connect, BDL or LDB purchase order or supplier invoice into GlobalTill. What is causing this?

Answer

The most common reasons for liquor order import failures are related to configuration of the deposit category and related SKUs. If your liquor import has failed, check for the following.

The DEPOSITS category name has been modified

Upon import, GlobalTill will look for the deposit products in a category called DEPOSITS.  If your store has recently changed the category name, including capitalization, the import functionality will fail. If you change the category name back to DEPOSITS, the functionality should resume.

To check the name of your DEPOSITS category, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > Product Management > Category Manager.
  2. Review the Category Listings to confirm the deposit category is entitled DEPOSITS (all CAPS).
  3. If the name of the DEPOSITS category has been modified, select it to change it back.

There are two SKUs for the same deposit amount in the DEPOSITS category

Upon import, GlobalTill will look for the related deposit product in the DEPOSITS category. If you have two SKUs in the DEPOSITS category for the same amount, GlobalTill will not know which SKU to select and the import will fail.

Review the SKUs in your DEPOSITS category and delete or move any duplicate deposit amounts to another category.

To check for duplicate deposit amounts, follow these steps.

  1. Go to Products > New List.
  2. Select Column Visibility to add the Category and Price: Unit/Retail Sell or Cost: Unit/Last Ordered Cost headers.
  3. Filter the Category to DEPOSITS.
  4. Use the sort arrows in the Price: Unit/Retail Sell or Cost: Unit/Last Ordered Cost header to sort the list in ascending or descending order. This will make it easier to spot duplicates.
  5. Remove any deposits of equal value from the DEPOSITS category.

      Heads up

    Setting the duplicate deposit product to inactive without updating the category won't resolve the issue because GT re-activates inactive products on incoming supplier invoices. You must remove the DEPOSIT category assignment from the product entirely, then set the product to inactive.

More Information

For more information, see the articles How to create or edit a category and How to create a DEPOSITS category.

articles.name: How to update customer order status
articles.title: How to update customer order status
articles.body:
How To

How do I update the status of a customer order?

Follow these steps

To update the customer order status, follow these steps.

  1. Select Update Order Info.
  2. Select the order status from the Status dropdown menu and select Submit.

More Information

For more information, see the article What does each customer order status mean?

articles.name: Why isn't sale price reflected at the POS?
articles.title: Why isn't sale price reflected at the POS?
articles.body:
Question

I put a product on sale and confirmed the sale price is active in the GT Backend by referencing the On Sale Now Price (shown below). When I scan the product at the POS, the regular price appears. Why?

Answer

If you've recently set up a sale and confirmed the sale price is active in the GT Backend, but the sale price is not reflected on the POS, you likely need to reload the product data on your POS station. Follow the steps below.

Reload data at the POS

  1. From the left hand side bar of the POS, select the Product List.
  2. Select Reload products.

articles.name: Why does my retail pricing rule price not match the GLS price
articles.title: Why does my retail pricing rule price not match the GLS price
articles.body:
Question

I set up a retail pricing rule and selected the Match bc liquor stores check box. Why does my retail pricing rule price not match the GLS price for some of my products?

Answer

In order for GlobalTill to match the GLS price, the product must have a GLS price and this price must have been updated within the last 30 days. GlobalTill intentionally does not price match to GLS sale prices. To determine the GLS price and last time the GLS price was updated, refer to the B.C. Data tab. 

Here are some examples.

Outdated price

Assuming today's date is May 9, 2021, this product would not be priced to match BC Liquor Stores as the GLS price was last updated more than 30 days ago. 

BC Liquor Stores sale price

Assuming today's date is May 9, 2021, this product would not be priced to match the BC Liquor Stores price. Despite being last updated within the last 30 days, the current GLS price is a sale price. In this case, GlobalTill would match to the standard GLS price of $25.49, plus any rounding specified in your retail pricing rule.

Successful price match

Assuming today's date is May 9, 2021, this product would be priced to match BC Liquor Stores as the GLS price was last updated within 30 days.

articles.name: Can I customize field mapping between GlobalTill and Shopify?
articles.title: Can I customize field mapping between GlobalTill and Shopify?
articles.body:
Question

Can I customize where GlobalTill data fields are mapped to in Shopify? For example, can I map the GT Brand field to the Shopify Vendor field?

Answer

Custom mapping is possible in some cases but is not supported by GT Support.

For example, the GT Brand is synced to Shopify under a metadata field. The metadata namespace is GlobalTill, and the value is the brand as it is in GT. This is not something that shows up in the normal Shopify UX, but an experienced developer will know how to configure with your theme.

articles.name: How to sort print order in visual template editor
articles.title: How to sort print order in visual template editor
articles.body:
How To

How do I sort the print order of shelf labels made using the visual editor?

Follow these steps

To sort the printing order of your shelf labels, follow these steps.

  1. Select File > Data Settings.
  2. Choose a field under Sort By and specify if it is ascending (ASC) or descending (DSC).

  3. The sort order will be applied to all labels made using the visual editor.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to print labels made using the visual editor.

articles.name: What is the compliance reporting weight
articles.title: What is the compliance reporting weight
articles.body:
What is…

What is the compliance reporting weight?

The weight referenced in the CTLS regulatory compliance reporting to be entered into Health Canada's Cannabis Tracking and Licensing System. 

More Information

For more information, see the article How to enter or edit compliance reporting weight.

articles.name: How to view products on a supplier invoice
articles.title: How to view products on a supplier invoice
articles.body:
How To

How do I view all the products on a supplier invoice?

Follow these steps

Use this feature to view the list of products contained on the supplier invoice in your Product List. This is useful for printing labels or troubleshooting cost errors. To access this feature, follow these steps.

  1. Select Purchasing > Supplier Invoices.
  2. Select the supplier invoice to open it.
  3. Select Actions > Open Product List.
  4. This will open the list of products contained on the supplier invoice in your Product List where you can press the green plus sign, or select the SKU number, to review detailed product information.

articles.name: Are shipping charges on orders imported from WooCommerce?
articles.title: Are shipping charges on orders imported from WooCommerce?
articles.body:
Question

Are shipping charges or delivery fees on orders imported from WooCommerce?

Answer

Yes. If you create a shipping SKU in GlobalTill, and assign the SKU as your store's default shipping charge, shipping charges will be imported from WooCommerce.

To ensure your shipping charge is set up correctly:

  1. Ensure your GlobalTill store has a shipping SKU setup so WooCommerce has a place to send the shipping charges. 
  2. Ensure the shipping SKU is assigned to be the Default shipping charge under Settings > Store Settings > Edit Store > Advanced Tab > Default shipping charge.

That's it! Now when the order is imported, shipping and handling fees will populate in a field on the customer order called order charge. When the order is converted to an invoice, GlobalTill will auto add the shipping SKU at the correct dollar value.

More Information

For more information, see the articles How to create a shipping charge and How to assign a default shipping charge.

articles.name: How to repackage a product
articles.title: How to repackage a product
articles.body:
Before you start

Create a SKU for the final repackaged product before you get started. Repacking requires both the original SKU and the repack SKU to exist in your database.

How To

How do I repackage a product?

Follow these steps

Repackaging a product involves modifying the number of units in a product that make up one unit of sale. A common example is repackaging one 24-pack of beer into four 6-packs, or breaking down one 6-pack for the individual sale of six single units.

To repackage a product, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List and search for the product you want to repackage.
  2. Select the Inventory tab, then select Repackage.
  3. Enter the Destination Product, the final product you're creating from the repack.
  4. Enter the Quantity Converting, the number of original units to be repackaged.
  5. Enter the Output Quantity, the total quantity of the destination product created from the repack. Select Submit.
  6. You'll be asked to verify the repackaging, select Submit to complete the repackage.

You can follow this process for any combination so long as the quantity of the repackaged product evenly divides into the case quantity. This process also works in the reverse, if you accidentally create one too many 6-packs from a 24, you can enter a quantity converting of four and output quantity of one to "re-assemble" the 24-pack.

Frequently asked questions

  1. How do I barcode a repackaged product?
    If you want to sell the repackaged product as both the new package (6-pack) and the original pack (24-pack), preface the barcode of the new product with an A, B, C, etc. When the product is scanned at the POS it will prompt the cashier to choose which product should be added to the invoice.

articles.name: How to add an opening balance to a customer profile
articles.title: How to add an opening balance to a customer profile
articles.body:
How To

How do I add an opening balance to a customer profile?

Follow these steps

Adding an opening balance to a customer profile will create an unpaid invoice with that balance. This function is typically used when a store wants to track money that a customer owes from a previous account or POS system.

To add an opening balance to a customer profile, follow these steps.

  1. Select Customers > List.
  2. Locate the customer and select View Customer.
  3. From the Advanced tab, select Add Opening Balance.
  4. Enter the Balance and the as of Date. Select Submit.

articles.name: How to copy barcodes from one location to another
articles.title: How to copy barcodes from one location to another
articles.body:
How To

How do I copy barcodes from one location to another?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Multi-Store > Copy > Copy Barcodes.
  2. Select the From store.
  3. Select the To store. Select Submit.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to copy products from one location to another.

articles.name: How to park an invoice
articles.title: How to park an invoice
articles.body:
How To

How do I park an invoice?

Follow these steps

To park an invoice before completing it at the POS, follow these steps.

  1. Select Actions > Park Invoice.

  2. Name the parked invoice so you can better remember the customer when you need to retrieve it again. After parking it, you will get a message that the invoice was successfully parked.

  3. When you are ready to retrieve the invoice, select Actions > Get Parked Invoice to be shown a list of all the currently parked invoices.

  4. Select the intended parked invoice, and continue to check out as usual.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to clear parked transactions nightly and How to enable full screen view of parked invoices.

articles.name: How to use application zoom level
articles.title: How to use application zoom level
articles.body:
Heads up

For the best visual experience, the POS should be used with screen resolutions greater than 1024 x 768 px. Lower screen resolutions may require you to scroll to see certain features and buttons.

How To

How do I use the application zoom level?

Follow these steps

Application zoom level is a setting that controls how magnified the POS looks. If you're having trouble seeing the entire POS on your screen, adjust the application zoom level. We recommend no higher value than 1.2 to avoid visual distortion.

To adjust the application zoom level, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the Core tab.
  3. Adjust Application Zoom Level.

articles.name: How to turn on detailed merchant receipt
articles.title: How to turn on detailed merchant receipt
articles.body:
How To

How do I turn on printing a detailed merchant receipt?

Follow these steps

Print Detailed Merchant Receipt allows stores to print detailed merchant receipts cash-based transactions as well as credit cards.

  1. Select POS Settings > POS.
  2. Turn on Print Detailed Merchant Copy.

articles.name: How to view previously applied retail price changes
articles.title: How to view previously applied retail price changes
articles.body:
How To

How do I view previously applied retail pricing changes?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Products > Pricing > Retail Prices.
  2. Select Actions Previous Applied Changes to see all changes recently been applied. 

 

More Information

For more information, see the article How to apply retail pricing rules.

articles.name: How to create quick add buttons
articles.title: How to create quick add buttons
articles.body:
How To

How do I add quick-add buttons, also known as Flip Charts, to the POS?

Follow these steps

  1. From the GT Backend, select Products > Advanced > Quick Add Flipchart.
  2. Select Actions > Add New Section. This creates the section where the button will be located on the POS. If your section already exists, skip ahead to step 4.

  3. Enter a Name for this section and select submit.

  4. Select the Section where you would like the button located.

  5. Select Actions > New Button. This will create the button at the POS.

  6. Choose the Product from the drop-down menu.

  7. Enter any Override Text. This will override the product description of the item at the POS. If you have a product called "Plastic Bags" for example, you might want to use the Override Text to call this item "bag".

  8. Decide whether you want to: 
    • Prompt for Price - This will prompt the cashier to enter a price.
    • Prompt for Description - This will prompt the cashier to enter a barcode and description (compatible with POS v3.1 and higher).
    • Negative Quantity - This option will add a negative price and quantity at the POS, this is typically used for items such as lottery redemption. 

More Information

To enable Quick Add Keep Open, so that the Quick Add Menu remains open on the POS until manually closed, see the article How to enable quick add keep open.

articles.name: How to delete a shelf location
articles.title: How to delete a shelf location
articles.body:
How To

How do I delete a shelf location?

Follow these steps

These instructions are used for deleting one location as opposed to all unused locations in the back office.

  1. Select Products > Product Manager > Location Manager. This gives you a list of all the locations you have in the Back Office.
  2. To delete a single location, select the minus (-) next to that location.

  3. Confirm you want to delete the Location. This operation cannot be undone.

articles.name: Where can I find the POS version number?
articles.title: Where can I find the POS version number?
articles.body:
Question

Where is the POS version number located?

Answer

The POS version number is located in the bottom left corner of your POS station.

articles.name: How to restrict sale pricing to customers only at the POS
articles.title: How to restrict sale pricing to customers only at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I offer my sale, flyer, or promotional price to customers with a profile only?

Follow these steps

Restrict Sale Pricing to Customers Only limits sales prices to customers who appear in your customer list. Sale prices won't be offered to walk-in customers when enabled.

To restrict sales pricing to customers only, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings.
  2. Select the POS tab.
  3. Enable Restrict Sale Pricing to Customers Only.

articles.name: How to add or edit a product image
articles.title: How to add or edit a product image
articles.body:
Before you start

Images are added via the Web Data tab. Make sure a product has web status enabled before you start.

How To

How do I attach images to products in GlobalTill?

Follow these steps

Images are often uploaded to GlobalTill in bulk using Admin Ops or the Web Data Import, but knowing how to access images in the UI is useful when you need make a change to a single product. To add or update an image on a single product, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List and open the product you wish to edit.
  2. On the Web Data tab, select Edit Web Data.
  3. Under Main Image, select Choose File to upload your main image. Upload a second image under Second Image. Select Submit.
  4. Images appear instantly on the Web Data and Images tabs in the GT Backend, and near instantly in GT Commerce. Images appear in integrations and at the POS after the next data sync.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to enable web product status.

articles.name: Getting Started with Price Book Strict Pricing
articles.title: Getting Started with Price Book Strict Pricing
articles.body:
Heads up

This feature is only available on GlobalTill 4.8.0+.

What is price book strict pricing?

Delivery services like Skip the Dishes and Uber Eats often include a mark up on retail prices in their service fee, sometimes this can be as high as 30%. Some stores choose to mark up prices on orders processed through these platforms to recoup the fees from the end consumer.

As a solution, we've implemented an additional customer flag, price book strict pricing, that can be used with the retail plus or cost plus price books. When enabled, the customer will receive the price book pricing at the POS, whether or not that pricing is lower than retail, the on sale price, or any other promotional price.

How does price book strict pricing work?

Once the price book is setup and assigned to the delivery customer profile, the price book prices override the retail prices on all orders processed at the POS under the delivery customer profile.

Some stores also create a new payment method that matches the name of the delivery service for tracking purposes, as payments are usually received direct to the retailer's bank account.

Using this system optimizes the workflow of delivery orders by increasing visibility and removing the requirement of having salespeople manually price override each line item at the POS to recoup the costs associated with delivery orders.

How do I configure GlobalTill to use price book strict pricing with a delivery service?

Create a retail plus price book

Setup a new retail plus price book to represent the prices you want to charge on delivery services. See the article, How to create a price book.

Create a customer profile for each delivery service

Setup a customer profile for each service you use to deliver. See the article, How to create a customer profile.

Assign the price book and price book strict pricing to the delivery service profile

Assign the price book to the profile you created, and check the the Price Book Strict Pricing box. See the article, How to apply a price book to a customer profile.

Create a payment method for each delivery service

Setup a payment method to be used only for orders processed through the delivery service. See the article, How to create a payment method.

  Heads up

If you don't set up a payment method for use with delivery services, we recommend setting the default terms to 30 and the credit limit to a number high enough to allow for charges to be processed. Default terms and credit limit are located on the Addresses, Billing and Pricing tab on the customer profile. See the article, How to edit a customer profile.

Redownload the data at the POS to sync the new price book, customer profile, and payment method 

At the POS select "..1" on the keypad to reload the POS data. See the article, How to redownload store data.

How do I apply price book strict pricing at the POS?

Once everything is set up, process all delivery orders under the delivery customer profile at the POS by following this steps.

  1. Start a new transaction on the POS, and select Customer.
  2. Search for and select the profile you created delivery service.
  3. Add products from the order to the transaction. You'll see the delivery mark up reflected as a reverse discount. Select Checkout.

      Heads up

    If there's a discrepancy in the dollar amount for any item as compared to the delivery service receipt, inform your manager. They can adjust the price using a price override.

  4. Select the payment method you created for the delivery service as the payment method, or on account if not using the payment method for this workflow.

What GlobalTill platforms is price book strict pricing available on?

Price book strict pricing is available on the following platforms.

  • GT POS on Mac and Windows.
  • GT Mobile (In progress, no current ETA).
  • GT Backend (Planning, no current ETA).

More Information

For more information, see the article What is a price book.

articles.name: Can I remove a location from online inventory if I use multi store inventory sync?
articles.title: Can I remove a location from online inventory if I use multi store inventory sync?
articles.body:
Question

I use GlobalTill's customized multi store inventory sync with my Shopify integration. How do I limit the inventory locations that offer the product online? 

Answer

To remove inventory from online availability in a specific location of a multi store set up, first set the product to non-active in the specific GlobalTill store.

After setting the product to non-active in GlobalTill, login to your Shopify account and unselect the box(es) beside the location(s) where the online inventory is to be removed (the location where you had previously set the product to non-active). In the Shopify UI, this is usually found under Edit Locations under a product's inventory header.

  Heads up

The product must be set to non-active in GT or the inventory boxes will be re-checked in the next data sync.

articles.name: How to create a shipping charge
articles.title: How to create a shipping charge
articles.body:
Before you start

You will need to have a supplier set up before you can create a shipping charge. For more information see the following article, How to create a supplier.

  Heads up

You will have the option to change the value of the shipping charge before you convert an order to an invoice.

How To

How do I create a shipping charge?

Follow these steps

To create a shipping charge, follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Select Actions > New Product.


  3. Enter a Product Code for your shipping charge (In example, SHIP).
  4. Enter a Product Name for your shipping charge (In example, Shipping Charge).
  5. Ensure the Is Inventoried box is unchecked.


  6. Select the Ordering tab and select a Misc. supplier from the dropdown. If you don't already have one set up see the following article: How to create a supplier.


  7. Select the Pricing tab and enter a Unit Sell value of $1.


  8. Select Submit.

Now when you are ready to convert a customer order to an invoice you can set the shipping charge you just created to be added as a line item, then you can set how much your shipping charge is, overriding the $1, and charging the customer accordingly.

More Information

For more information on shipping charges, see the following articles:

  • How to assign a default shipping charge
  • How to add a shipping charge to a customer order

articles.name: How do I change the example SKU in visual template editor?
articles.title: How do I change the example SKU in visual template editor?
articles.body:
Question

How can I change what example product shows in my template in the visual template editor? How do I set the example SKU in the template editor?

Answer

When creating a template, the visual template editor references from the most recently updated or added product.

To change the example SKU, locate the product you wish to use as the example SKU, select Actions > Edit Product, select Submit, and return to the template editor. Note that you do not have to make any actual changes to the product.

articles.name: Why does my report show a negative profit?
articles.title: Why does my report show a negative profit?
articles.body:
Question

Why do some of my GlobalTill reports show a negative profit or negative profit margin?

Answer

When one of your GlobalTill reports is showing a negative profit or negative profit margins, it usually means on of the following:

  1. one or more of your frequently sold products is being sold below cost
  2. the current cost on the item is higher than the retail price

Unless under certain circumstances, the cost for a product will generally be lower than the retail price. If you see a cost of $300.00 on a product that you are selling for $30.00, we recommend double checking this item.

If you generate a Daily Sales Report and that has a negative profit, we suggest pulling a Detailed Sales Report to conduct a review on the specific products that were sold. 

  1. Select Reporting > Report List > Sales Detail > Detailed Sales Report.
  2. Select the Excel format. This will make it easier for you to search and sort the report.
  3. Select the Date Range where your profit was negative.
  4. Select the Optional Columns tab.
  5. Include the following columns to give you further insight into why the profit was negative.
    • Optional Field: Avg. Cost
    • Optional Field: # Sold (Gross)
    • Optional Field: # Returned
    • Optional Field: # Sold (Net)
    • Optional Field: Gross Sales
    • Optional Field: Net Returns
    • Optional Field: Discounts
    • Optional Field: Cost
    • Optional Field: Profit
    • Optional Field: Margin

Another helpful report to review is your Daily Store Overview Report, which gets emailed daily or can be pulled on-demand from Reporting > Report Archives.

Reference the Product Warnings tab of the report, look for products with a retail price below cost. 

More Information

For more information on how to correct any cost errors identified in the above reports, see the articles How to correct a cost average and How to correct a product unit cost.

articles.name: How to enter or edit compliance reporting weight
articles.title: How to enter or edit compliance reporting weight
articles.body:
How To

How do I enter or edit a product's compliance reporting weight?

Follow these steps

To enter or edit compliance reporting weight, follow these steps:

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Locate the product and open it.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Product.
  4. Select the Other tab.
  5. Enter the value into the Compliance reporting weight field.

articles.name: How to review previously ignored price changes and suggested price change details
articles.title: How to review previously ignored price changes and suggested price change details
articles.body:
Heads up

If you've recently issued price changes, you can skip the first three steps and download a copy of the most recent pricing rule activity from the Archived Reports under Reporting > Archived Reports > Suggested Price Changes.

How To

How do I see what price changes I've previously ignored, or a summary of why a retail price was suggested?

Follow these steps

Ignoring price changes pauses suggested changes for products for a period of days. Review what price changes you've previously ignored and for how long, or access a breakdown of why a retail price was suggested with the Suggested Price Changes report. Follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > Pricing > Retail Prices.
  2. Select Actions > Check for New Price Changes.
  3. Check Send Email Summary to receive an excel copy of the suggested price changes. This report shows you details of each suggested retail price change, including the price changes that currently ignored.
  4. To find the price changes you've ignored, filter the Special Criteria column in the report.  Look for Rule Ignored Until...

articles.name: FAQ - Click and collect integrations
articles.title: FAQ - Click and collect integrations
articles.body:
Heads up

This support article has been created for integration partners who may participate in support requests from shared GlobalTill clients. This article focuses primarily on cannabis, but the basic fundamentals apply to most integrations.

Question

Is there a main database with all products shared and accessible to all members of a retail organization, regardless of their location? 

Answer

This will vary by organization. Depending on set-up, retailers may work from a multi or single store environment. As a general rule of thumb, most clients with multiple locations work from a centrally managed main environment which houses all product data. Typically, not all members of an organization have access to the main environment.

If a GlobalTill enduser reaches out, it's best to confirm if they are working from a single store or multi store location first.

  • Single store users have product information contained to one environment. Troubleshooting is based on data in that environment only.
  • Multi store users have access to a specific dataset pushed out from their organization's main environment. Troubleshooting multi store user inquiries is based on data in both the local and main environments.

Question

What does order fulfillment look like in GlobalTill?

Answer

The order fulfillment process is dependent on how the integration is set up. Talk to your development team to confirm the nature of your integration. Fulfillment will likely fall under one of the following.

Orders sent to the POS

    • These orders can be paid or unpaid, and appear under Parked Orders at the POS. For more information, see the article How to process a parked order from the POS.

Orders sent to the GT Backend

    • Selling > Customer Orders
      • The orders can be paid or unpaid, and require manual processing. For more information on processing a customer order, see the article How to process a customer order.
    • Selling > Invoices
      • These orders often come in fully paid, with little to no processing involved.
      • The paid invoice will simply appear under Selling > Invoices. This type of setup can be difficult to manage as there are visibility limitations as to where an order is sitting in the fulfillment cycle. Refer to the organization's operational guidelines to determine the troubleshooting and fulfillment processes. 

Question

Where does a retailer enter the product name in GlobalTill?

Answer

The product name is entered into the Product Name* field on the basic information tab on a product's information page. Access this field from a product's details page by selecting Actions > Edit Product from the top right corner. Entry/edit access is accessible only from single store environments or from the main environment in a multi store set up. 

The API endpoint for product name is product_name.

All users, including those in a local environment in a multi store set up, can confirm a product name on a product's details page. The product name is located in the top right.

Question

Can product names vary between main and local environments?

Answer

No. The main environment syncs the product name as-is to linked locations. The product name in the main environment will be an exact match to the name in the local environment.

Question

Can retail price vary between main and local environments?

Answer

Yes. The retail price field is flexible. Retailers have the option to set prices centrally and send into local environments via price zones for a group of stores, or to a single store. Some enterprise clients have a mix of price zone and single store pricing. 

Question

If there are multiple batches of the same product, will they have the same SKU number?

Answer

Yes. The batch is recorded as part of a SKU's product details. This is recorded when the product is received but is not directly accessible from the GlobalTill user interface.

Question

Where does a retailer enter the price in GlobalTill? Are there any additional fields for special pricing tiers?

Answer

A product's retail price is entered in the Retail Price field on the pricing tab on a product's information page. Typically, multi store environments upload prices to the main environment in bulk and sync to local environments based on price zone.

In all environments, the current retail price is reflected on the pricing tab of a product's details page in the field Retail Price. The API endpoint for the retail price is retail_price.

A product's sale price is entered into GlobalTill through the promotions menu. If a product is on sale, there will be an additional On Sale Now Price field on the pricing tab above the regular retail price field. The API endpoint for the sale price is sale_price.

GlobalTill does provide Price Book functionality to offer customer based discounts, although the use case varies. Please reach out to GlobalTill Support for more information on if your integration supports the use of Price Book pricing.

Question

What is the web name field referenced in the API? How is this different from the product name and what is this predominantly used for?

Answer

The web name is the consumer-friendly product name displayed on the web and select in-store signage. The web name is usually shorter than the product name and does not include qualifiers often used in retail naming conventions, such as size or strain. When the web name field is left blank, the product name field is referenced by default. 

Question

Are units deducted from inventory when an order is received in GlobalTill or when the transaction is completed?

Answer

When an order is parked at the POS, or in the Customer Order List in the GT Backend, the inventory status for each product on the order changes from Available for Sale to Dedicated to Customers. When the transaction is posted, inventory is deducted from the main inventory location. 

Review inventory status on the inventory tab of a product's details page. In the below, we have 43 units total, 4 units are reserved for customer orders and 39 are available for sale.

Question

How does a product get passed through the API? Is it just an Active flag on the item? Is it tied to an inventory room that also has to be set to Active?

Answer

The web product flag in the product's attributes determines whether or a not the product will pass through the API. If a product is missing from your integration, confirm web product status is enabled by looking for the Web Data tab on the product's details page.

If there is no Web Data tab, advise the client to enable web product status for this product. See the article How to enable web product status for instructions.

Question

What lab results are collected in the POS and how do they come through the API?

Answer

Lab results are pushed into GlobalTill through another integration partner and are not available in the API by default. We anticipate this being available in the near future.

Question

Does GlobalTill have global and/or category threshold settings?

Answer

There are no threshold settings aside from the federally mandated 30 gram purchase limit for products with an equivalent grams value > 0.01.

Some retailers opt to set up quantity buffers per category to ensure walk-in retail operations will not affect other channels. To check if a connected quantity buffer is in place, first find out the name of the top level category for the product in question, then go to Products > Product Management > Category Manager. Select the category name and refer to the Connecter quantity buffer* field.

In the example below, there is a two unit buffer applied to all products in the Edibles category. This means there must be at least three units in the inventory location Available for Sale for the product to be reflected as in stock via the integration channel.

Question

Does GlobalTill have purchase limit settings?

Answer

GlobalTill enforces a purchase limit of 30 grams to be compliant with federal government legislation, provided a product has accurate and complete product data.

Question

How do specials work in GlobalTill?

Answer

See the article How to create a sale for information on setting up and managing promotions in GlobalTill.

articles.name: How do bottle deposits work with WooCommerce?
articles.title: How do bottle deposits work with WooCommerce?
articles.body:
Question

How do bottle deposits work with WooCommerce?

Answer

Deposit configuration is managed on the WooCommerce side. In GlobalTill, all that is needed is a deposit product equal to the amount of the deposit charged in WooCommerce. The GT Backend will push deposit product data to WooCommerce, which is then used to configure an additional plugin to assign bottle deposits to products in WooCommerce. 

There are a variety of apps available for charging additional fees. Some use conditional rules to map fee (deposit) application to tags or product attributes like size or deposit.

Because there are a multitude of ways to configure deposit use in WooCommerce, it's best to reach out to your WooCommerce developer for set-up or if you are experiencing issues.

In our experience working with deposits, if a deposit is charged in GT and not charged in WooCommerce, it's likely that the deposit has not been set up for the specific amount in the plugin used on your site. We recommend reviewing the plugin configuration to ensure mapping is accurate and the deposit exists in the amount you are charging.

To review WooCommerce plugins, follow these steps.

  1. Login to you WooCommerce Admin panel.
  2. From the left hand side menu, select Plugins.
  3. Locate the plugin used in your store. Most plugins display additional options under their name, including Settings, Support and Documentation which you can use to troubleshoot further.

articles.name: How to generate a purchase order for outstanding customer orders only
articles.title: How to generate a purchase order for outstanding customer orders only
articles.body:
How To

How do I make a purchase order for outstanding customer orders only?

Follow these steps

In addition to automatically generating purchase orders based on minimum quantities, you also have the option to generate purchase orders based on outstanding customer orders only and exclude any minimums that have been set in GlobalTill. This is useful for wholesalers to be able to order everything they need to fulfill customer's orders but ignoring minimum quantities.

Follow these steps:

  1. Select, Purchasing > Purchase Orders.
  2. Select  Actions > New PO. This will give you a blank PO.
  3. Choose the Supplier, Order Date, Dates Expected (required).  Supplier Reference, Sub Vendor, Other Reference, and Notes are optional.
  4. Select Submit.
  5. Select  Actions > Orders Only PO.
  6. Your purchase order is generated, showing you everything you need to order based on outstanding customer orders.
  7. Before you send your purchase order,  you can change it before by clicking the Edit or Delete buttons.
  8. You can also select Columns to view more information such as On Hand, Minimum, Customer Orders, Oder Multiplier, Product Size, Category, Units Per Case, Already Coming, and Pending Returns, and Weekly Averages.
  9. You can also add new products that are not included in the purchase order by select New.
  10. (optionally) You can now convert Purchase Orders to Supplier invoices by choosing the purchase order and selecting Actions > Convert to Supplier Invoice.  This is particularly useful for non-integrated suppliers by saving you from manually enter product quantities. When you convert a PO to a supplier invoice, if any line on the PO is set to quantity 0, that line will not transfer over to the supplier invoice.

articles.name: What is the difference between adjustment and count
articles.title: What is the difference between adjustment and count
articles.body:
What is…

What is the difference between an inventory count and an adjustment on the product inventory tab?

While both an inventory count and an adjustment change the on-hand quantity of product, each is flagged differently in the GT Backend. Once a count is posted, the Inventory Tab on a product's detail page is also updated. When adjustments are made due to an inventory count, it is marked as Count. When you adjust product inventory through the Adjust button, it will be marked Adjustment.

articles.name: How to add an account contact to a customer profile
articles.title: How to add an account contact to a customer profile
articles.body:
How To

How do I add additional account contacts to a customer profile?

Follow these steps

Add a billing, ordering, or administrative contact to a customer profile by following these steps.

  1. Select Customers > Lists.
  2. Select View Customer.
  3. From the Account Contacts tab, select Add Contact.
  4. Enter the Customer Contact Information and select Submit.

articles.name: How to print an invoice
articles.title: How to print an invoice
articles.body:
How To

How do I print an invoice in the GT Backend?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Selling > Invoices.
  2. Locate the invoice and select View.
  3. Select Actions and choose your print preference.
  4. Choose the Template you wish to print and select Submit.

articles.name: How to receive a deposit on a customer order
articles.title: How to receive a deposit on a customer order
articles.body:
How To

How do I receive a deposit on a customer order?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Selling > Customer Orders. 
  2. Select the Blue Arrow next to the customer order number to open it.
  3. Select Actions > Receive Deposit.
  4. Enter the deposit Amount, Payment Method, and Authorization number (if applicable). Select Submit.
  5. The deposit and payment details will be reflected at the bottom of the customer order under the header Order Payments.

articles.name: How to edit a reference number and date on a posted invoice
articles.title: How to edit a reference number and date on a posted invoice
articles.body:
How To

How do I change a reference number or date on an invoice that has already been posted?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Purchasing > Supplier Invoices.
  2. Select the invoice with the incorrect date or reference number.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Reference.
  4. Enter the Supplier Reference or Date of Invoice and select Submit.

articles.name: How to copy product descriptions from one location to another
articles.title: How to copy product descriptions from one location to another
articles.body:

How do I copy product descriptions from one location to another?

articles.name: How to enable the on screen keyboard at the POS
articles.title: How to enable the on screen keyboard at the POS

How do I enable on the on screen keyboard at the POS?

This setting enables an on screen keyboard in select areas of the POS, so you can type without a physical keyboard.

To enable the on screen keyboard, follow these steps.

articles.name: How to print an order number on a receipt
articles.title: How to print an order number on a receipt

How do I show the customer order number on POS receipts?

When Print Order Number is enabled, the order number will print on customer receipts. To enable Print Order Number, follow these steps.

articles.name: How to delete unused shelf locations

articles.body:

articles.name: How to reposition quick add buttons
articles.title: How to reposition quick add buttons
articles.body:
How To

How do I reposition quick add (flip chart) buttons at the POS?

Follow these steps

To reposition the flip chart buttons at the POS, follow these steps. 

  1. Select Products > Advanced > Quick Add Flipchart.
  2. Using the arrow buttons to the right of each section, you can move the section up (left) or down (right). You can also delete a section altogether.

  4. If you want the changes to occur immediately at the POS, reload store data.

articles.name: Tips for using GlobalTill if your operations have changed due to COVID-19
articles.title: Tips for using GlobalTill if your operations have changed due to COVID-19
articles.body:
Many retailers have modified day-to-day business to protect both their staff and the public during the Coronavirus crisis. Whether it's hosting senior-only shopping days, reserving hours for the most vulnerable, or offering delivery or drive-up services— our clients are doing what they can to keep their doors open for business and serve the public safely.

We admire your ingenuity during these difficult times! And we wanted to highlight some GlobalTill features you may not regularly use to make your work a little easier.

Using the Customer Ordering System 

If you aren't already creating customer orders within GlobalTill, now might be a great time to start doing so. If you are taking more customer orders by email or over the phone these days, you should consider Customer Orders within GlobalTill. It gives you the ability to create the orders in GlobalTill's back office, pick and scan the orders, and then generate an invoice once the customer is ready to pick up. 

Some retailers try to skip the customer orders altogether and leave invoices in draft in the GT Backend until a customer pays the invoice. This is not recommended (or even supported). Leaving invoices "in draft" makes it more difficult for you to keep track of what inventory is actually in stock, and to reconcile your sales figures later. It also increases the chance for errors.

Instead, we recommend the following process:

  1. Create a Customer Order in GT Backend.
  2. Use Notes to enter a customer's address if you will be delivering.
  3. Add Dates to the orders to prioritize what you are going to be fulfilling today versus what you might be filling tomorrow. You can sort by date in the order list.
  4. Take a pre-payment deposit on the Customer Order, which is then applied to the invoice (optional).
  5. Invoice the order the moment that the customer takes the merchandise.
  6. Manually record the payment at the time the customer pays, regardless of whether it's upon invoice or weeks later.

Important Notes About the Customer Order System

  • When you use customer orders, you cannot make payments at the POS. You need to know how to record the payments in the Back Office manually. We've included links to support articles on both customer orders and manually recording payments at the end of this article.
  • The Customer Order feature is NOT suitable for Cannabis products unless used via an integration.

Pre-Creating Invoices at POS

Rather than create orders or invoices in the Backoffice, some retailers find it more convenient to use the POS to pre-create the invoice before the customer visits the store. In this case, you can:

  • Scan in the products at the POS to create the invoice.
  • Park the invoice until the customer enters the store to pay for the merchandise. 

Using a Portable Debit Machine

Some clients opt to bring a portable debit machine out to customer's vehicles for payment, or take it with them for delivery, rather than have them come into the store. If you don't have a portable debit machine, most payment processors offer both WiFi and 3G/4G versions. Stick to 3G/4G for delivery if you aren't sure how far your WiFi coverage extends outside your building.

After taking the payment on the mobile terminal, you can record the amount in GlobalTill one of two ways depending on your process and whether you created the order in the Back Office or POS.

  • Process the payment manually at the POS by selecting Show More, then choose the card type (Visa, MasterCard, Debit, etc.)
  • Or, record the payment manually in the Back Office.

Frequently Asked Questions

Can I make a payment on an invoice created in the Back Office on the POS?

No. You cannot currently bring up an invoice created in the Back Office on the POS for payment. You can either recreate the invoice on the POS or manually enter the payment on the Back Office. 

Can I add a shipping charge for delivery?

Yes. Depending on your processes (such as whether you use GlobalTill's customer ordering system), shipping charges can be added. This support article explains one method. 

These are uncertain and challenging times for everyone! We wish you good health and safety and look forward to a time when the Coronavirus outbreak is safely behind us.

Contact us if you have any questions. We're here to help!

More Information

For more information, we recommend the following support articles on these topics:

  • How to create a customer order and How to process a customer order
  • How to record a payment on an invoice
  • How to take a manual payment method at POS

articles.name: How to use the tax modification button
articles.title: How to use the tax modification button
articles.body:
Heads up

Tax modification must be enabled at the POS before using the instructions below. For more information, see the article How to enable tax modification at the POS.

How To

How do I use the tax modification button?

Follow these steps

The tax modification button allows salespeople to overwrite the default tax rate at the POS with one specified in the POS settings.

To modify tax rates applied to an order, follow these steps.

  1. Scan the products into the POS.
  2. Select Tax Mod to apply the new rate, this can be undone by selecting it again.
  3. The tax will be updated to the modified rate.

More information

For more information, see the article How to flag a customer profile as tax exempt.

articles.name: How do discounts sync to WooCommerce?
articles.title: How do discounts sync to WooCommerce?
articles.body:
Question

How do discounts created in GlobalTill flow into WooCommerce?

Answer

The On Sale Now Price in GlobalTill is populated when a product is discounted.

When the GlobalTill On Sale Now Price is populated for a product, GlobalTill will push this as the Sale price ($) in WooCommerce.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to create a sale.

articles.name: How to complete a cash transaction at the POS
articles.title: How to complete a cash transaction at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I complete a cash transaction at the POS?

Follow these steps

To complete a cash transaction, follow these steps.

  1. Select Checkout after all products have been scanned and the customer (if any) has been selected.
  2. Select Cash as the Method of Payment.
  3. Enter the amount received or choose one of the Quick Cash buttons and select Enter.
  4. The POS will update with the amount due if payment is still required. Otherwise you'll see the invoice for the order with change owing at the top of the screen and email/printing options for the receipt. Select Done to complete the transaction and return to the POS

  Heads up

If you have the setting Do not print customer receipts enabled in the settings you will be returned to the POS screen once payment is complete with the change due in the Last Change widget.


More Information

For more information, see the article How to split payments at the POS.

articles.name: How to flag a customer profile as wholesale
articles.title: How to flag a customer profile as wholesale
articles.body:
How To

How do I flag a customer profile as Wholesale?

Follow these steps

This setting marks the customer as wholesale, which differentiates it for reporting and ordering purposes depending on your stores settings. To flag a customer profile as wholesale, follow these steps.

  1. Select Customers > List.
  2. Select View Customer beside the customer which you would like to designate as wholesale.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Customer.
  4. From the Basic information tab, check the Is wholesale checkbox. Select Submit.
  5. You will be returned to the customer profile to see the Type field updated to Wholesale.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to create a customer profile.

articles.name: How to add or remove columns from visibility on a customer order
articles.title: How to add or remove columns from visibility on a customer order
articles.body:
How To

How do I add or remove columns from visibility on the customer order screen?

Follow these steps

You can add additional columns to your customer order screen to increase visibility and make processing orders easier. To add or remove columns from the customer order screen, follow these steps.

  1. Open any Customer Order.
  2. Select the Column Visibility button.
  3. Select columns to add or remove. Visible columns will be highlighted in blue.

articles.name: Why is my template generating blank fields for some products?
articles.title: Why is my template generating blank fields for some products?
articles.body:
Question

Why is a field or fields in my template generating without information for certain products? 

Answer

If you have generated a template that displays complete information in the visual template editor, and on other labels or invoices that you have printed from the template, the most likely cause is missing or incomplete data for these products in GlobalTill. 

For example, if your template references a promotional price, but is printing a blank box in the promotional price field for certain products, look up the products in question and double check that they each have a promotional price entered.

articles.name: What is quantity available
articles.title: What is quantity available
articles.body:
What is…

What is quantity available for sale?

Available for Sale is an inventory status that represents the number of units in inventory that are available for sale. To calculate the quantity available for sale, GlobalTill takes:

  • The Quantity On Hand

  • MINUS (-) quantity Dedicated to Customers through customer orders

  • MINUS (-) quantity Pending Return to Vendor through supplier invoices

  • MINUS (-) quantity in select unsaleable inventory locations

articles.name: What is the Other (compliance) category
articles.title: What is the Other (compliance) category
articles.body:
What is…

What is the Other category?

This is an additional category that is often used by cannabis retailers to record the category referenced in Health Canada's Cannabis Tracking and Licensing System (and the related CTLS Reporting). 

More Information

For more information, see the article How to assign or edit a product's Other category.

  Heads up

Before assigning the Other category to a group of products, review your reporting requirements. Unlike the Category and Sub/SubSub Category designations, the Other category is not included in most standard retail reports.

articles.name: What is the health check indicator
articles.title: What is the health check indicator
articles.body:
What is…

What is the health check indicator? Why is my health check indicator red?

Located on the top-right corner of the POS, this health check indicator will turn red if your POS station cannot connect with the GlobalTill cloud.

Don't worry. Your POS station works without Internet, so you can still service customers. The POS will sync with the GT Backend once the connection is restored.

Troubleshooting a red health check indicator

When your health check indicator is red, here are a few things to check before you reaching out your support contact:

  • Reboot your computer. Reboot your computer and reopen the POS.
  • Check your Internet connection. Check to make sure your Internet is working. Open a web browser and try connecting to a website. If your Internet isn't working, check your router, cables, or reach out to your service provider.
  • Check your POS API endpoint. Follow these steps.
    1. From the menu bar, select Edit > Change API Endpoint Connection.
    2. Enter the GlobalTill URL used when logging into the GT Backend. This is usually https://office.globaltill.com, but reach out to your support contact if you are unsure. Select Save.

  • Disconnect from the POS, reconnect and perform a Health Check. If the above has not resolved connectivity, follow these steps.
    1. Logout of the POS.
    2. Enter “.14” in the keypad.
    3. From the left hand side bar, select the bottom most option. Then select your POS station from the system list.
    4. Logout of the POS again.
    5. Select a user, then type in exactly “hc” and press LOGIN. If successful, you will see the indicator turn from red to white.

    After the connection is restored

    Once the connection between the POS and GlobalTill is restored, the health check indicator will turn white after several minutes.

    After an Internet outage, we also recommend clicking the white health check indicator, which will sync products and customer data with the backend.

articles.name: What role does GlobalTill play in the set up and management of a Shopify integration?
articles.title: What role does GlobalTill play in the set up and management of a Shopify integration?
articles.body:
Question

What role does GlobalTill play in the set up and management of a Shopify integration?

Answer

GlobalTill provides end-user support in the form of general guidance, “how-to” support, and problem troubleshooting.

GlobalTill does not provide assistance or direction on the set up and configuration of third-party application integrations or third-party plugins outside of the GT platform.

We recommend contracting with a platform-specific expert to perform the integration if you are not technically capable. Reach out to GlobalTill support if you would like the contact information of a recommended service provider.

articles.name: How to create and assign a container deposit to a product
articles.title: How to create and assign a container deposit to a product
articles.body:
Before you start

Container deposits must be assigned to the DEPOSITS category. Deposit products assigned to any other category will impact your ability to use GT's automated features, including the PO and Supplier Invoice imports. For more information, see the support article How to create a DEPOSITS category.

How To

How do I create and assign a container deposit to a product?

Follow these steps

A container deposit is a minimum refundable deposit on beer, soft drinks, and other beverage containers used to encourage recycling or reuse. The container deposit amount varies from province to province.

In Alberta, a 12 pack of 355 mL cans of beer has a deposit of $1.20. A 750 mL bottle of wine has a deposit of $0.10.

GlobalTill pre-loads standard container deposits to Alberta and B.C. Liquor stores at set-up. However, standard deposit amounts may not cover all use cases as the size and quantity of containers sold as a singular unit may vary.

To charge a container deposit and do not have a matching deposit in your store, follow these steps.

Step 1: Create a deposit product.

  Heads up

If deposit products already exist in your database, skip this section and start from Step 2: Attach the deposit to the product.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Select Actions > New Product.
  3. Enter a Product Code that identifies it as a deposit product (ex. D00010 for .10 deposit).
  4. Enter a short, but descriptive Product Name to identify it as a deposit (ex. Deposit(s) $0.10).
  5. Select a Category. The category has to be called DEPOSITS. If you do not have this category you will need to create it.
  6. Ensure that Is Inventoried is unchecked.
  7. Ensure that Apply Tax to Product is unchecked.
  8. Select the Pricing tab. Set the Unit Sell field to deposit cost and ensure the Allow product to be Discounted is unchecked.
  9. Select Submit.

Step 2: Attach the deposit to the product.

  1. From the Products List, select the product that requires the deposit.
  2. Select Actions > Edit Product from the product detail page.
  3. From the Basic Information tab, check Auto Add Deposit. Then select the correct deposit from the Deposit dropdown list. This will ensure that the deposit is added to that product.

articles.name: How to delete quick add buttons
articles.title: How to delete quick add buttons
articles.body:
Heads up

Remember to redownload the POS data after changes are made in the GT Backend so they are updated at the POS. For more information, see the article How to redownload store data.

How To

How do I delete a quick add button at the POS?

Follow these steps

To delete a quick add button at the POS, follow these steps.

  1. Go to Products > Advanced > Quick Add Flip Chart.
  2. Select the Delete icon of the quick add button you want to delete. 

  3. You will be asked to confirm the deletion, this cannot be undone.

articles.name: How to use the purchase order list
articles.title: How to use the purchase order list
articles.body:
How To

How do I use the purchase order list? 

Follow these steps

To familiarize yourself with how to use the purchase order list, follow these steps.

  1. To view the purchase order list, select Purchasing > Purchase Orders.
  2. To view or hide additional information like Status, Date Expected, Unit Quantity, and Case Quantity, select the Columns button.
  3. Columns can be filtered by typing in the Search field at the top of each column. Columns can be sorted in ascending or descending order by clicking on the up and down arrows at the top of each column.
  4. Use Clear All Filters to clear any search filters.
  5. Hide or unhide closed purchase orders by checking Hide Closed POs.
  6. To open a purchase order, select the value in the Supplier or the Reference column.
  7. Select Actions to create a New PO, Bulk Generate POs, Upload an XLSX PO File, or Bulk Close Old POs. See the More Information section for links to support articles on these functions.

More Information

For more information, see the articles:

  • How to create a purchase order
  • How to bulk generate purchase orders
  • How to upload a generic purchase order file
  • How to bulk close purchase orders

articles.name: How to copy pricing from one location to another
articles.title: How to copy pricing from one location to another
articles.body:
How To

How do I copy pricing from one location to another?

Follow these steps

  1. Select Multi-Store > Copy > Copy Pricing.
  2. Select the Copy to Store. Select Submit.

More Information

For more information, see the article How to copy products from one location to another.

articles.name: How to enable the system name at the POS
articles.title: How to enable the system name at the POS
articles.body:
How To

How do I display the name of the POS station at the POS?

Follow these steps

System name is a setting that displays the name of the station in a badge at the main POS screen.

To enable the system name at the POS, follow these steps.

  1. Access the POS Settings. 
  2. Select the Core tab.
  3. Enable System Name.

articles.name: How to print a QR code with transaction ID on receipts
articles.title: How to print a QR code with transaction ID on receipts
articles.body:
Heads up

A 2D barcode scanner is required to read a QR code.

How To

How do I print a QR code containing transaction information on my POS receipts?

Follow these steps

When enabled, Print QR Code will print a QR code on the receipt at the POS. The QR code can be used to look up the original transaction in the backend or optionally validate a return.

To print a QR Code on POS receipts, follow these steps:

  1. Access the POS Settings.
  2. Select the Printing tab.
  3. Enable Print QR Code.

Frequently asked questions

  1. Why doesn't my QR code scan with my barcode scanner?
    A QR code requires a 2D barcode scanner. Verify that your hardware is compatible.
  2. I don't have a 2D barcode scanner. Can I manually enter the transaction ID under the QR code at the POS?
    No. The QR code must be scanned at the POS. If you don't have a 2D barcode scanner, we recommend disabling the Original Transaction ID return requirement in the POS settings.
    • Access the POS Settings.
    • Go to the POS tab.
    • Select Return Info.
    • Turn off Original Transaction ID.
  3. How do I rule out format issues with the QR code?
    Most cellular phones allow you to scan QR codes using the built-in camera app. Open your camera app and point it steadily for 2-3 seconds towards the QR code you want to scan. The transaction code should appear.

More Information

For information about how to add a customized QR code to POS receipts, see the article How to insert HTML content into customer receipts.

articles.name: Where do I find an inventory valuation?
articles.title: Where do I find an inventory valuation?
articles.body:
Question

Where do I get a per SKU breakdown of inventory in my store at a given point in time?

Answer

The Inventory Valuation Detail report provides a per SKU breakdown of the inventory value in your store at a specified point in time. This report includes SKU, product, category, location, historical cost average, quantity and value, with optional columns for deposits, size and subcategory.

To generate an inventory valuation, follow these steps.

  1. Go to Reporting (Beta) > Report List > Inventory.
  2. Select Inventory Valuation Detail.
  3. Enter the report parameters. If required, use the Optional Columns tab to include container deposits, subcategories or sizes in your valuation. Then select Submit to generate the report.

articles.name: How to flag a customer profile as tax exempt
articles.title: How to flag a customer profile as tax exempt
articles.body:
How To

How do I flag a customer profile as tax exempt?

Follow these steps

To flag a customer profile as tax exempt, follow these steps:

  1. Select Customer > List.
  2. Locate the customer and View.
  3. Select Actions > Edit Customer.
  4. Select the Address, Billing & Pricing tab.
  5. Scroll to the end of the form and check Tax Exempt.
  6. Enter the Tax Exemption Number. This can also be a registration number such as a business number that exempts a customer from taxes at the point of sale.
  7. Select Submit.

articles.name: Reporting specifications and guidance
articles.title: Reporting specifications and guidance
articles.body:
Heads up

The new GT Reporting module is part of GlobalTill's Early Access Program (EAP) and may be subject to change. Learn more about EAP here, Early access program policy.

Report List

The Report List summarizes high level report information and includes:

  • The Role of who might benefit from using the report
  • The Recommended Use of how often to pull the report
  • A unique report code used by GlobalTill support to identify the report and version number
  • A Learn More link with a breakdown of report fields

Learn More

The Learn More area summarizes report specific details and includes:

  • Benefits - What information and insight the report provides
  • Variations - How the data is presented in the report, e.g. by week, by month, by year
  • Column Definitions - Column number from left to right, column names and definitions, the format of the data in each column, and whether or not the column is optional

articles.name: How to enter or edit a barcode (cannabis)
articles.title: How to enter or edit a barcode (cannabis)
articles.body:
Heads up

The barcode referenced in select regulatory compliance reporting is a separate data point called the Compliance Code. For more information on where to enter the Compliance Code, see the More Information section at the bottom of this article.

How To

How do I add, edit, or remove a product's barcode?

Follow these steps

To add, edit, or remove a product's barcode follow these steps.

  1. Select Products > List.
  2. Select the Barcodes tab, and then select Add Barcode.



  3. Add the Barcode by either typing it manually or scanning it. To scan the barcode,  your scanner must be in Keyboard Wedge mode. Click or tap within the Barcode text field before scanning the product. You can add multiple barcodes to a single product.
  4. Enter the Quantity that should be recorded when the barcode is scanned. Under normal circumstances, when you add a barcode that number should be 1 unless you want it to scan as a case.
  5. Select Submit to save the changes.
  6. Edit a Barcode by selecting the existing barcode from the list.
  7. Use the Red X to remove the barcode.

More Information

For more information see the articles:

  • What is a compliance code
  • How to enter or edit a compliance code in the main environment
  • How to enter or edit a compliance code in a single store environment
  • What is the difference between a barcode and a compliance code

articles.name: How to import a BDL order
articles.title: How to import a BDL order
articles.body:
How To

How do I import my BDL order into the GT Backend?

Follow these steps

GlobalTill accepts BDL order imports from both the BDL Order Confirmation and the BDL Invoice Portable Document Format (.PDF) files. To import a BDL order into the GT Backend, follow these steps.

  1. Select Purchasing > Advanced > BDL Upload.
  2. Select Select File and choose your BDL order import file. This can be either the Order Confirmation or the Invoice Portable Document Format (.PDF) file.
  3. (Optional) Check Create products if they don't exist to auto-create the products on this order that don't currently exist in the product list.
  4. The BDL order will be imported into GlobalTill and can be accessed under Purchasing > Supplier Invoices.

Frequently asked questions

  1. What happens if I check Create products if they do not exist?

    • The GT Backend will automatically create a new product if no matching product is found in your database. Products are identified based on the SKU. On the BDL documents, this is referred to as the Item No.
    • The product name in GT is taken from the Product Description column in the BDL document and a double asterisks (**) is added to the end to make this easy to identify.
    • The default supplier will be set to Brewers Distributors Ltd.
    • The category is set to Default.

    We recommend you review and amend products after they are created. Specifically:

    • Set a retail price.
    • Add a barcode.
    • Add a bottle deposit.
    • Change the Category, SubCategory and SubSubCategory.
    • Update the product name in GlobalTill.
    • Review the default units per case and order multiplier (if applicable).
    • Any other product setup that is applicable to your store.

articles.name: Release Notes for November, 2020

GT Backend

🎉 New

🤓 Other
